articles.content:
MBUSA requires authorized Mercedes-Benz dealers to return certain replaced warranty parts and assemblies which fail during the New Vehicle Limited Warranty, Extended Limited Warranties, the Emission System and Performance Warranties, and the Service Parts and Accessory Warranties period, for reconstruction and testing.

We highly recommend shipping and scrapping parts daily. You must track warranty/goodwill returns to ensure receipt by MBUSA. Tracking can be done through the NetStar Shipped Parts tab or the Warranty Scorecard / % Parts Not Returned (click on the magnifying glass to see/export a list of parts dispositioned for return).

Parts with defects found prior to installation should be returned to the Parts Distribution Center (PDC). Please refer to the Parts Assistance Center (PAC) website for the specific policies and procedures regarding the return of parts found with defects prior to installation.

The Parts Handling Allowance for the majority of parts replaced under warranty and recalls/campaigns is an amount equal to the part’s current MBUSA Dealer Net price, plus a parts handling allowance. MBUSA Dealer Net reimbursement amounts/prices are determined from current parts prices in effect on the date of repair.

No parts handling allowance will be reimbursed/paid on parts replaced that meet the following criteria:

  • Cores - Parts designated as “Core” parts; Core parts have a core return value
  • Local purchase parts
  • Sublet repairs - Non-MBUSA parts installed/supplied by a Sublet Repair facility
  • Pre-Paid Maintenance Packages (parts are claimed at MSRP price)
  • Tires

Major Assemblies Parts Handling Allowance

  • 30% parts handling allowance

This includes supplies such as cleaning materials (brake cleaner, pure benzene, cold cleaning solvent, etc.) or expendable materials (antiseize, emery cloths, shop towels, cutting and sanding disks, contrast agents for finding oil leaks, leak detector for air brakes, adhesives, grit, etc.) that are wholly or partially expended during W&G repairs and not installed into the vehicle.

rh:doc.headline: PC 9.7 Excusing Warranty Parts and QEC Reimbursements
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 9.7 Excusing Warranty Parts and QEC Reimbursements

articles.content: All parts requested for return to the QEC (Return Dispositioned in NetStar) must be shipped within 7 days of notification.

Parts not received within 45 days of claim payment will be debited. If you find the part after a debit has been issued you will have 30 days to return the part and have the debit reversed. Any part received after 30 days from the debit date will be returned to you as a debited part. Requests to excuse parts must be made prior to the debit via a WSG Parts Disposition case or within 45 days of claim payment.

If after 3 weeks from shipping you find any part that still shows ‘Not Received’, please create a WSG case so that the QEC can investigate and respond to you in a timely manner.

While it is best to resolve discrepancies prior to the debit we will entertain Non Return Part form appeals for 15 days after parts have been debited for non-return.

Parts may be excused for these circumstances:

• Add-On parts

• Part fell off the vehicle while driving

• Parts incorrectly dispositioned for return to the QEC

Parts will not be excused for these circumstances:

• Part was accidentally thrown out

• Part cannot be found

• Part was billed out in error

• Part was sent to the PDC as Customer Pay core in error

Note: We suggest that you separate the warranty/goodwill and customer pay core storage areas to help eliminate errors in which parts are sent to the PDC as Customer Pay cores.

rh:doc.headline: PC 9.3 Local Purchases

articles.content: Warranty claims require the use of genuine Mercedes-Benz parts that are purchased directly from MBUSA.

When a genuine Mercedes-Benz part is not sold by/available from MBUSA, if directed by MBUSA, a Local Purchase of the respective part is claimable under warranty. Prices for Local Purchase parts should not exceed what the current local market price is for the item(s). MBUSA expects the dealer to procure the best price locally for the Local Purchase part/item. Please note that Local Purchase claims are subject to review by MBUSA. If it is determined that there is an excess or abuse in submission of Local Purchase claims, these claims will be reviewed.

Note: All Local Purchase parts must be itemized on the repair order to substantiate the cost claimed. Do not list local purchase items in the sublet field. Under no circumstances should other manufacturer's part identification numbers be used in place of MBUSA’s abbreviated descriptions for local purchase items.

rh:doc.headline: PC 9.2 Remanufactured Parts / Parts with Cores
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 9.2 Remanufactured Parts / Parts with Cores

articles.content:
Remanufactured units must be used when replacing assemblies under warranty for vehicles that have been put into service (retailed/demo/consigned). The dealer must order remanufactured versions (example 80 suffix) where a remanufactured program exists.

Note: Remanufactured units must NOT be installed when making replacements of assemblies on vehicles which are still in dealer stock/inventory. These replacements must be fitted with NEW parts.

Note: When parts have an 80 suffix the system will convert the part number to a 60 and add the 70 part number for the actual CORE value.

• If the PDC substitutes a new unit when the dealer ordered a remanufactured unit, a copy of the delivery note must be attached to the claim, with an explanation that a new unit was substituted for a rebuilt unit.
  • If a remanufactured program exists but a new part is installed, dealers will be paid for the new part price minus the core value (DNET - core value) and will not be paid handling on the core value. Some new parts will have cores even if a remanufactured program does not exist.
  • The price for the “60” suffix is the DNET of the original part minus the core value. The core is not paid on the warranty claim because it is reimbursed when the part is returned.
  • Several versions of a remanufactured unit may be available for a particular model year. Later versions are not to be used to upgrade earlier version units. Warranty replacements must be made using the exact version.

rh:doc.headline: PC 9.9 Warranty Parts Handling and Disposition
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 9.9 Warranty Parts Handling and Disposition

articles.content: MBUSA requires authorized dealers to return certain replaced warranty/goodwill parts and assemblies that are submitted on a warranty/goodwill claim which fail during warranty the NVLW, ELW, Emission System and Performance Warranty, and the Service Parts and Accessory Warranties period, for reconstruction and testing.

Before returning warranty/goodwill parts a Dealer must:

  • Externally clean all parts.
  • Drain all fluids and reinstall all required plugs and caps on appropriate components.
  • It is essential that the fluids are drained from the following assemblies:
  • Engines
  • Rear Axle Center pieces (differentials)
  • Long Blocks
  • Transfer Cases
  • Short Blocks
  • Power Steering Pumps
  • Transmissions (Automatic and Standard)
  • Transmission valve bodies
  • Injection Pumps
  • Fuel related parts

Note: Failure to drain all fluids or reinstall plugs and caps will result in a HazMat charge of $100.00.

  • Reassemble all parts which have been disassembled before they are returned to MBUSA.

Note: Failure to reassemble the parts will result in a claim debit.

  • Repackage components in Original Parts Container
  • Affix Warranty Parts Tag (W-420), Identified by Repair Order, directly on replaced part with Bar Code Label on the tag.
  • Retain parts at the Dealer until disposition is given in NetStar (Disposition occurs the day after the claim hasbeen submitted).
  • Mark all visible defective areas of warranty/goodwill parts, particularly rims/wheels, trim parts, glass, wood, leather, MB-Tex, seat covers, floor mats, steering wheels, soft tops, transmissions, engines and steering racks. Parts must be marked only with a wax pencil by the Mercedes-Benz dealership’s technician or warranty parts handler. Failure to clearly mark the damage with a wax pencil will result in the claim being debited if the defect cannot be confirmed during parts testing.
  • Create and print parts return and parts scrap reports through NetStar.

Additional Requirements:

  • Non-defective parts will be returned to the dealer when requested.
  • Defective replaced warranty/goodwill parts, which are required to be returned to MBUSA, will be requested after the claims have been submitted to MBUSA through NetStar, as follows:
    • Disposition for warranty/goodwill parts is given through the NetStar Disposition system.
    • All replaced hazardous parts returned for warranty/goodwill consideration must be shipped in the original container observing all applicable government safety regulations concerning the shipping of warranty/goodwill components classified as hazardous material.
    • The airbag or ETR is NOT to be deployed prior to shipping. For those items which are received in a deployed state, warranty claims will be debited.

Note: It is the responsibility of the dealer to follow all government regulations regarding the shipping of warranty/goodwill components classified as hazardous materials, including the training of personnel.

  • Parts replaced under warranty/goodwill are the property of MBUSA. MBUSA will instruct the dealer on the disposition of subject parts (scrap or return). MBUSA will dispose of warranty/goodwill parts as they see fit and will not be liable in any way.

Note: MBUSA reserves the right to change the warranty/goodwill parts return policy at any time.

rh:doc.headline: PC 9.1 Parts Replacement and Documentation

articles.content: Whenever a warrantable repair is performed, only MBUSA supplied new or remanufactured Mercedes-Benz parts may be installed. The removal of parts from an in-stock or other “like” vehicle to be used as replacement parts on any warranty repair is strictly prohibited. Warranty repairs do not constitute an extension of the original warranty period for the vehicle or part thereof.

The dealer must maintain an accurate parts inventory control system and record of purchases. An adequate inventory of parts must be maintained to conduct service and warranty work promptly. Dealers must also maintain controls to ensure that the minimum number of essential parts is used in completing a warranty repair.

MBUSA requires that any warranty parts be replaced with the same version removed, unless the same part version is no longer available. Any upgrading of the vehicle or replacement parts is not admissible.

If a remanufactured part is currently not available or on backorder a new part can be used. A NON OEM part cannot be substituted unless directed by official documentation from MBUSA. It is required that a pdf copy (screenshot) showing that the part is not available must be attached to the claim and also retained in the vehicles Service History file. If a copy is not attached to the claim, the claim is subject to debit.

• Parts issued and used for warranty repairs must be purchased from MBUSA or via another approved MBUSA system (Dealer Locator and D2D) and traceable in the parts inventory system. Only those parts which are necessary and pertinent to a warrantable repair may be submitted for reimbursement.
  • In instances of an incorrect part installation due to an error in XENTRY Parts Information, please use Damage Code 00404 01 for claim submission purposes.
  • In instances where a part has an extended backorder and all prescribed part escalation steps have been exhausted, and where a higher assembly is available which would resolve the situation, open a case for assistance. The Warranty team will then assess the situation and, if justified, approve the higher assembly. Upon receiving approval, all documentation of the backorder must be submitted with the claim. Claims submitted without a) prior approval and b) proper documentation on the backordered part will be subject to debit.
  • Parts with defects found prior to installation should be returned to the Parts Distribution Center (PDC). Please refer to the Parts Assistance Center (PAC) website for the specific policies and procedures regarding the return of parts found with defects prior to installation.
In this section topics pertaining to parts handling, parts records and parts return are addressed. For information on Over the Counter Parts and Spare Parts Warranty please refer to Policy 7.5.

rh:doc.headline: PC 8.5.1 Emergency Service Repair – Customer Pay
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 8.5.1 Emergency Service Repair – Customer Pay

articles.content: Emergency service not covered under MB Emergency Service Repair will result in customer pay - customer's responsibility.

The customer may make payment by cash, credit card or personal check depending on dealer policy.

Customer Pay

MBUSA’s Travel Allowance Reimbursement in addition to Customer Pay:

Day - For travel between the hours of 7:00am and 12:00 midnight $ 0.00

Night - For travel between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00am $25.00

($25.00 from MBUSA is in addition to customer pay)

Damage code Emergency Service Repair-Customer Pay claims if performed between Midnight and 7:00am to: Roadside Assistance Customer Pay Midnight to 7:00am - 21 404 00

Payment Default -The customer may make payment by cash, credit card or personal check, depending on the policies of the dealer. MBUSA guarantees checks and major credit cards accepted by dealers up to $300.00, provided proper care was taken to identify the owner and all reasonable means of collection were used. Two attempts to reach the customer by registered mail must be made to collect an outstanding bill before submitting a claim of non-payment to MBUSA.

Claim Submission information for Dealer Payment Protection claims:

  • Damage code 21 445 00 must be used
  • All claims must be booked according to warranty policies and procedures
  • All parts and labor must be claimed (not grouped as a sublet)

Mercedes-Benz Emergency Service Repair Policy provides limited repair services by a factory trained technician, if available, in the event of a breakdown due to a warrantable defect and the vehicle is covered by the MBUSA New Vehicle Limited Warranty (NVLW), Mercedes-Benz Extended Limited Warranty, CPO (Certified Pre-Owned Limited Warranty) or Spare Parts Limited Warranty. Due to the variety of special tools, parts and diagnostic equipment that are required to repair Mercedes-Benz vehicles, there are limitations as to what can be repaired by a technician in a roadside environment. Repairs done on an Emergency Service Repair must follow Warranty Policy with proper diagnostic and repair procedures as outlined in and not limited to WIS, TIPS (LIs). This also may include the use of required tools such as and not limited to XENTRY machine, Midtronics ESP-717 tester, etc.

****Does not apply to Non-U.S. vehicles****

Note: An Emergency Service Repair is different from the Roadside Sign and Drive Service.

Dealer may submit a claim for reimbursement covering both parts and labor. Decision for eligibility done at the dealership. Time cannot include travel time to and from the Mercedes-Benz Dealer. Damage as a result of road hazards, debris, accidents, or "acts of nature" (flood, lightning strikes, tree falling on vehicle, etc.) is not covered.

Claim Submission: A repair order consisting of two repair lines should be used.

  • First line includes labor as per XOT, parts and handling
    • damage coded to failure causing part
  • Second line includes
    • Additional 50% labor of repair from first line billed as labor op 00-9627. Damage code according to the failed part and using “Damage Type” P3
    • Travel Allowance must be submitted as a Sublet
      • Day - For travel between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight reimbursement is $50.00
      • Night - For travel between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. reimbursement is $85.00

Note: The technician cannot determine whether a particular repair at the breakdown site is covered by warranty. Determination of warranty coverage is to be done at the dealership prior to claim submission.

Note: Should the technician determine the vehicle requires towing to a Mercedes-Benz repair facility; please contact the CAC and arrange the tow through the Roadside Assistance Program.

Mercedes Benz USA, LLC will cover the cost of towing for repairs that are covered under the New Vehicle Limited Warranty (NVLW), Mercedes-Benz Extended Limited Warranties (ELW), Certified Pre-Owned (CPO) Limited Warranty and Spare Parts Warranty.
For all Roadside Assistance (CAC) inquires please visit their website

Tows arranged through Roadside Assistance (CAC): There is no need to submit a Repair Order for the tow fee when arranged through Roadside Assistance (CAC).

Tows arranged outside Roadside Assistance (CAC): In the event a tow is arranged by the Mercedes-Benz Dealer or the customer and not through Roadside Assistance (CAC), the tow fee should be claimed on the same Repair Order as the warranty repair. Create an additional line as follows:

  • Damage code to the failure causing part
  • Damage Type “P4:”
  • Claimed Tow amount in “Sublet” field.
  • Create an ESKULAB from the claim to obtain authorization from the Field Representative.

On occasion, a Mercedes-Benz vehicle owner may encounter a warrantable failure when a Mercedes-Benz Dealer service center is not available, either due to the location of the vehicle or to avoid unreasonable inconvenience. If the owner decides to obtain repairs normally covered by warranty, from an independent garage or non-Mercedes-Benz facility, it is the interest of good owner relations that the dealer reimburse the owner. In these instances, the dealer must check whether:

  • Requirements for warranty or goodwill case were met
  • Repair was carried out with genuine parts or material approved by the manufacturer
  • Repair situation was an emergency
  • Authorized service center could not be reached at reasonable expense
  • Invoice is plausible
  • Expense was economically justified
  • Removed part must be obtained from owner/independent garage or non-Mercedes-Benz facility for dealer to verify manufacturing defect.

The dealership may reimburse the cost of the warrantable repair as follows:

  • The dealer must generate a repair order and attach the original invoice to the hard copy of the R.O.
  • The dealer must submit a warranty claim using the sublet code: "SUB"
  • Claims will not be paid unless there is a complete and detailed explanation in the text field.

• The owner complaint requiring the special order part must have been received and documented on a previous repair order.
  • The dealer must have ordered the part promptly, (i.e. the same day or the next day business day following the documented owner complaint).
  • Back ordered parts or items that are not normally stocked in the average dealer (e.g. Color coded trim items, coded locks, seat covers, ect.) are the only parts that qualify.

For Claim Submission:

Date: _______________
Mileage: _____________

The dealer must enter the original RO date and mileage of when the original RO was opened and the part ordered.

rh:doc.headline: PC 8.1 Parts Ordered with Vehicle Under Warranty, But Installed Post Warranty
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 8.1 Parts Ordered with Vehicle Under Warranty, But Installed Post Warranty

articles.content: The owner complaint requiring the special order part must have been received and documented on a previous repair order while the vehicle was still under warranty.

The following conditions must be met:

  • The dealer must have ordered the part promptly, (i.e. the same day or the next day business day following the documented owner complaint).
  • Back ordered parts or items that are not normally stocked in the average dealer (e.g. Color coded trim items, coded locks, seat covers, etc.) are the only parts that qualify.
  • The dealer must make every effort to install the ordered part before the expiration of the warranty coverage period.
  • The installation must be done promptly upon receipt of part.
  • The dealer must enter the original RO date and mileage of when the original RO was opened and the part was ordered in the respective fields on the claim submitted.

The following provide information dealerships need to know prior to submission of certain claim types. These claims require special information and may also require the dealer to set up tables in the dealer’s management system (DMS) to prompt the dealer for certain information.

articles.content:
There may be an instance where the vehicle’s current mileage will be discrepant with the mileage in the VMI. There are procedures that must be followed for verifying and updating the mileage of a vehicle prior to submitting a warranty claim.

  • One of the first steps that the dealer must take in order to avoid rejection of claims for mileage is to check the last mileage recorded on the RO history of the VMI (Vehicle Master Inquiry). This step will almost always eliminate a mileage discrepancy from occurring.
  • MBUSA recommends that the dealer ALWAYS run a VMI before working on a vehicle to verify warranty eligibility and previous reported mileage.
  • The dealer must retain a copy of the VMI for their records.
  • In instances where a true mileage cannot be verified / determined after the vehicle has left, contact the Field Representative to have Status R applied and then open a case for assistance with claim submission. If the vehicle is present at the dealer, the dealer needs to open a TIPS case and if TMU is determined MBUSA will apply Status 9 to the vehicle.

Mileage discrepancy is reported via Master Data Correction from the Vehicle Information tab in EVA. To see instructions on how to file a Master Data Correction please visit the Supplementary Documents.

articles.content:
Field Representative Authorization is required in cases which may not be covered by standard warranty. Authorization to submit a claim is not a guarantee for payment. All claims are subject to MBUSA review and the decision to accept the claim is subject to all normal edits. Obtaining prior approval does not relieve the dealer from completing the claim with all necessary information or providing required documentation.

Field authorization requires prior approval of a repair through email as well as an ESKULAB through EVA, attached correspondence on the claim only does not suffice.

The following repairs require Field Representative prior approval:

  • All Product Liability, Safety and/or Fire Related Problems
  • Goodwill claims for vehicles over 8 years and/or 100,000 miles (calculated from Production Date - not Warranty Start Date)
  • Goodwill claim lines over $3500
  • Lease Payments and Goodwill ELW in these situations contact your Field Representative prior to making any offers.
  • Check NCUs and Goodwill Quick Reference Guide for the most up to date requirements on prior authorization.

All approved parts replacements or repairs must be:

  • Performed promptly following Field Representative authorization/approval

MBUSA Field Representative warranty claim authorizations are provided and submitted as follows:

  • The MBUSA Field Representative is required to review the repair documentation with regard to the applicability of the work and compliance with MBUSA documentation and repair requirements.
  • Upon approval by the Field Representative, the Field Representative will issue the authorization of the warranty claim through ESKULAB.
  • Utilize the ESKULAB coverage application which will generate a six-digit authorization number to be sent to the Field Representative for authorization.
  • The authorization by the Field Representative does not supersede required claim preparation procedures or acceptable repair techniques.
  • Goodwill Policy must be followed when using Field Representative Toolkit Damage Code
  • Parts replaced in connection with Field Representative authorized repairs must be made available for inspection at the discretion of the MBUSA Field Representative and submitted to MBUSA as requested by the NetStar Parts Disposition system.

rh:doc.headline: PC 7.5 Spare Parts and Over The Counter Parts Warranty
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 7.5 Spare Parts and Over The Counter Parts Warranty

articles.content: MBUSA warrants coverage for defects on genuine service replacement parts including customer pay, Recall/Service Campaign and Goodwill. Over-The-Counter parts warranty applies when the new defective part, which was originally purchased over-the-counter through an authorized Mercedes-Benz dealership by the owner, and the now defective part was not originally installed by an Authorized Mercedes-Benz Dealer. Repairs done under warranty do not constitute an extension of the warranty period for the vehicle or part thereof.

• The dealer must verify the original customer pay invoice or over-the-counter parts purchase receipt provided by the owner to confirm that the now defective part was originally purchased by the owner within the Warranty coverage period. If the vehicle has a new owner, the new owner will need to provide the invoice from when the part was purchased by the previous owner.
  • The original customer pay invoice or Over-The-Counter parts purchase receipt for parts must be dated within allowable time as stated below of the warranty complaint date.
    • 24 months / unlimited mileage (valid on parts sold as of January 1, 2017)
    • Transmissions: 24 months or 24,000 miles, whichever comes first, from date of purchase.
    • Engines and long blocks: 48 months or 50,000 miles, whichever comes first, from date of installation.
    • Wiper Blades 12 months / 12,000 miles, whichever comes first, from date of purchase (valid on parts sold as of August 6, 2020)
    • Brake Linings 12 months / 12,000 miles, whichever comes first, from date of purchase (valid on parts sold as of August 6, 2020)
    • Control Units Flash - Any control unit that receives a software flash carries a parts warranty of 12 months from the Repair Order date on which the flash was performed which covers the software flash only not the complete component.
  • The original customer pay invoice or Over-The-Counter parts purchase receipt must be retained in compliance with record retention policies
  • A copy of the original parts invoice must be attached to the claim in EVA. If a copy of the original parts invoice is not attached to the claim, the claim is subject to debit
Note: Coverage should always be checked using the original RO open date, as some maintenance and wear items could have reduced coverage.

• If the defective Over-The-Counter part has a warrantable defect, the dealer supplies a replacement part without installation.
  • Dealers can also be reimbursed for labor for the repair or replacement of parts which were originally sold over the counter, if the subsequent repair is performed at an authorized Mercedes-Benz Dealer.
  • Parts replaced under a Recall/Service Campaign/DSA/Goodwill performed outside of warranty carry the full Mercedes-Benz Spare Parts warranty.
  • Dealer Repairs:
    • Claims for over-the-counter part dealer repairs/installation are submitted in the same way as a replacement of previously replaced part claim containing the full VIN and proper mileage.
  • Non-Defective Parts: Over-The-Counter (OTC):
    • The dealer is responsible for testing the defective part to verify that the defect is subject to the MBUSA Over-The-Counter Parts Warranty.
    • Claims will be debited for parts, labor and parts handling allowance if no defect can be established during parts testing at MBUSA or for items which have been damaged by improper repair methods from the installer.
    • MBUSA suggests that dealers assure that their wholesale and retail owners are aware of this recovery policy.
  • Over-The-Counter (OTC) claim requires the following claim entries:

    • Part Number

Note: Vehicles on Status 3 (Stolen) are not eligible for spare parts warranty. Vehicles on Status 9 (Warranty Voided) require prior Field Representative approval for spare parts warranty.

Repairs for any glass replacements can be submitted as either an in-dealer repair (with applicable labor operations, parts and handling) or as a sublet for the replacement of the glass. When submitted as a sublet, the claim must abide by the requirements for sublet submissions.

  • Glass components include: Front Windshield, Rear Glass, Side Windows (front/rear) and the Sunroof/Panorama Roof.
  • Claims for mechanical defects in the sunroof/panorama roof frame, or side window mechanical components (regulators and attachments) are not covered by this policy and must abide by normal warranty repair polices in this manual.
  • Claims for defects in components in the windshield (heater / multifunction camera, etc.) and rear glass (defroster / antenna grid, etc.) for which the glass is replaced or damages where glass is replaced as a result of primary loss ARE covered by this policy and must conform to requirements within this policy.
  • Glass component replacement claims require photos of the affected area to be attached to the claim. Photos must include: 1) Photo of entire window while still on vehicle with damage circled, 2) Photo of damaged area (zoomed in/focused) and 3) VIN plate from B-Pillar or seat base of driver’s seat (location dependent on vehicle model). See link below for examples of acceptable photos. If photos are not attached to the claim, the claim is subject to debit. This is in addition to reviewing the Parts Disposition screen and returning parts (if applicable) to the QEC.

All repairs involving paint must be submitted as a sublet and the claim must abide by the requirements for sublet submissions.

  • For paintwork repairs, a paintwork damage sheet must be completed and retained in the Vehicle Service History File. Forms based on model can be found on: WIS > Table of Contents > Organization > OF Forms > Paintwork, FG 98
  • Any parts replaced must be provided by the dealer and listed on the RO and listed on the warranty claim for payment. MBUSA will only reimburse for OEM parts provided by the dealer and submitted on the warranty claim.
  • Paintwork repairs for paint defects or body/paint work due to component replacement (Example: failing door hinge caused damage to door and fender and now requires replacement and painting of door and fender) require pictures (pdf copy) of the affected area attached to the claim. Photos must include: 1) Photo of larger area on the vehicle with damage circled, 2) Photo of damaged area (zoomed in/focused) and 3) VIN plate from B-Pillar or seat base of driver’s seat (location dependent on vehicle model). If photos are not attached to the claim, the claim is subject to debit.

Sublet repairs are repairs that are performed outside of the dealership in a 3rd party Repair Facility/vendor. Authorized Mercedes-Benz dealers are required to maintain adequate service facilities, equipment, and trained personnel in order to meet and handle the service requirements of Mercedes-Benz vehicles. It is the dealership’s responsibility to ensure that any sublet repairs which they commission are performed up to Mercedes-Benz standards and follow all Mercedes-Benz procedures and work instructions.

When submitting a warranty claim for a sublet repair where the parts are being supplied by the dealer to the third party performing the repair, the dealer must list them separately on the RO and claim. The sublet should only include the labor and those materials not supplied by the dealer and not available from MBUSA. Following this procedure will generate a parts disposition, so please ensure that the parts are available for return if requested.

  • Mercedes-Benz reserves the right to determine what is reasonable and allowable with regard to a sublet repair.
  • The sublet bill must include the following:
    • Sublet company name
    • Sublet company address
    • Sublet company phone number
    • Date of services provided
    • VIN number of the vehicle being repaired
    • Dealer Code Number
    • Dealer Repair Order Number
    • Description of the work performed
    • Itemized list of parts used on repair (either provided by the dealer or provided by the sublet company)
    • Total charges billed for repair
  • A copy of the original Sublet Invoice must be filed with the hard copy of the RO in the vehicle service history file, and a copy of the original Sublet Invoice must be filed with the accounting copy of the repair order. The original Sublet Invoice must be filed with Accounts Payable files by Vendor Name.
  • A copy of the original Sublet Invoice must be attached to the claim. If a copy of the original Sublet Invoice is not attached to the claim the claim is subject to debit.
    • Attachments are not required for taxes or fees required to be claimed according to local and state laws. However if there are multiple fees or taxes that must be submitted, they must be listed individually with a description.
  • The invoice must list any no charge dealer supplied factory parts and the cost of any miscellaneous parts supplied by vendor. The amount of labor charged and the sources used to determine those charges must be stated. Proof of payment must be included in the repair order.
  • Sublet repairs must use new Mercedes-Benz parts or re-manufactured parts authorized by MBUSA. Any replaced part from the repair must be retained by the dealership as with any in-house claim.
  • Submission of unnecessary sublet repairs performed as a result of any improper diagnosis will be denied.

Claim for repairs or services performed outside the dealership such as towing, transportation, glass, upholstery, electronics repair, body shop, etc., must include the following information:

  • Sublet explanation – brief description accounting for need of sublet
  • Accurate description and information from the vendor on the work performed
  • Sublet vendor name, address and phone number
  • Pre-printed sublet invoice number
  • Sublet dollar amount with separate parts and/or labor totals
  • Complete parts listing with related parts numbers
  • Sublet purchase order number and related RO number
  • Date of repair and mileage
  • VIN of the repaired vehicle
  • Proof of payment (i.e. Purchase Order Number)
  • No parts handling allowance on NON OEM parts
  • Damage code to failure causing part

A basic and concise explanation of the complaint, cause and correction is all the text that is required on the claim. Any additional diagnosis, repair or parts that are claimable beyond the base repair operation require enough text to support what is being claimed.

It is recommended that text is supplied for all claims. Providing an explanation may decrease the chance of claim denial or delay in claim payment.

  • Intermittent problem
  • Delivery note # if PDC substitutes a new unit for an exchange unit
  • Parts ordered during warranty, that are installed after the warranty expires
  • Thorough explanation of additional components being replaced which were damaged as a direct result of the primary failed warranted part. (Note: Submit on same R.O. line.)
  • Repair item sublets
  • Same day replacement of replacement claims
  • Any repair performed based on any MBUSA published document or PTSS case must list the complete document number or case number in the Dealer Text and the scenario number if applicable.

rh:doc.headline: PC 7.2 Service Advisor and Technician ID
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 7.2 Service Advisor and Technician ID

articles.content: The Service Advisor and Technician's DPMS (Dealer Personnel Maintenance System) IDs are required when submitting a warranty claim. The DMS ID needs to match exactly what is in DPMS. Make sure no duplicate IDs are used. Certain repairs require Technicians to have specific certifications and if they do not have them, the claim may not be allowed for submission.

IDs will be validated against DPMS to ensure that the IDs entered in the warranty claim match the ID numbers in DPMS. The IDs being used must be from employees employed at the time of the RO open and close date.

The dealer is responsible for proper warranty claim submission in regard to warranty repairs and claims. The repair order is the source document for warranty claim preparation, therefore the information on the repair order must be clear, complete, and concise. The submission of a warranty claim by the dealer certifies that the dealer has performed the repair as stated on the repair order without charge to the owner.

  • Any payment made to a dealer for a warranty or policy repair can be charged back to the dealer at a later date if it is determined that the payment was not justified.
  • If MBUSA discovers that a dealer has submitted isolated and inadvertent false reports or statements relating to pre-delivery inspection, testing, warranties, service, repair or maintenance required to be performed by dealer, MBUSA shall notify and counsel dealer of such findings to prevent recurrence of such events.
  • MBUSA may charge a dealer for the cost incurred in the replacement of an owner's vehicle or for the refund of the purchase price paid by an owner for his/her vehicle when the replacement or refund is attributable to the dealer's failure to properly and adequately provide appropriate repair service.

For submission instructions please refer to the EVA and RAPS Reference Guides. The following information is not all inclusive, but are requirements to be included on each claim submitted by the dealer:

  • MBUSA Dealer Code / Dealer Name
  • Repair Order Number
  • Repair Order Line Number - The repair order line number is the actual line number of the repair order that generated the claim. Repair order line number can be alpha or numeric. MBUSA recommends the use of alpha. In case of resubmission of a previous resubmission the repair order number must remain the same.
  • Proper Maintenance - Check box indicates that vehicle service is up-to-date and dealer has supporting service records. If "no" is selected, this indicates that the vehicle has not been serviced accordingly and/or dealer is unsure causing claim to go to manual review to determine if improper maintenance contributed to the failure.
  • Damage Code
  • Repair Date - Both the open and close dates are required for warranty claim submission. This also applies to dealers using a handwritten repair order system
    • Dealers using an invoicing system created by DMS may use the invoice date as the close date. This date must be immediately following the date of the technician's last punch time.
  • Mileage
    • Miles In - Mileage recorded upon receipt of vehicle.
    • Miles Out - Mileage recorded after repairs are completed.
  • U.S. VIN/FIN number
  • Service Advisor ID
  • Technician ID
  • Sublet
  • Replacement Parts
  • Operation Number and hours
  • For RAPS a Case, Activity or Authorization number may be required

This section details specific conditions under which warranty claims are reimbursed. Warranty reimburses one time to properly correct a customer’s concern for a manufacturing defect. Only one claim can be submitted, no partial repairs.

A ZM labor operation has an established labor operation number but there is no established time. ZM labor operations are subject to the following policy:

  • Labor time requested for ZM operations cannot exceed the actual clock punch time specific to the respective repair. When a ZM operation code is claimed in both diagnosis and repair, you may not exceed 100% efficiency on the repair order line it applies to. The time being claimed must be reasonable and if applicable should not exceed the total established times in XOT necessary for disassembly to access the repair area.

Each dealership is responsible for monitoring the amount of labor that they claim and should maintain a process in-house for doing so. It is the dealership's responsibility to ensure that the amount of labor being claimed is qualified and necessary prior to claim submission.

Note: A separate punch is not required for Standard ZM op codes.

Note: A separate and identifiable punch is required for Diagnostic Time.

MBUSA recommends that each dealership's process for monitoring claimed labor hours includes a method to check the amount of labor being claimed (e.g. an internal approval process). MBUSA provides a Warranty Scorecard via NetStar for each dealership to use. It is recommended that the "Hours Per Damage" KPI is monitored regularly to help track excessive labor. MBUSA will regularly monitor the Warranty Scorecard for deviations at individual dealerships. Deviations could result in actions but not limited to: claim review, warranty audits, parts inspection, removal of add-on privileges, etc.

Standard ZM Operation Code Example:The technician replaced the transmission. The total punch for the repair was 6.9 hours.The technicians story states he removed, replaced and reinstalled the transmission. In this example, the claim would be booked in the following fashion:

  • 27-2029 Remove/install automatic transmission 6.2 hours
  • 27-2150 operation code ZM .7 hours (which equals the total elapsed time minus the time from the established labor operations performed)
ZM Policy Exception: Diagnostic Labor Operations are unique and are to be handled as follows:

Diagnostic ZM Operation Code Example:The technician replaced a left side widget. The total punch time for the repair was 1.4 hours. Included in the total punch time was 1.2 hours of diagnostic time supported by a separate identifiable punch. The technician's story explains that they performed a Short Test, the guided tests outlined by SDS and then replaced the left side widget. In this example the claim would be booked in the following fashion:

  • 54-1011 Short Test 0.2 hours
  • XX-0640 or XX-0641 operation code 1.0 hrs (Diagnostic Time 1.2 hrs – Short Test 0.2 hrs = 1.0 hrs)
  • XX-XXXX Replace left side widget 0.4 hours (time as listed in XOT)
The total time paid for this repair would be 1.6 hours and the technician is more than 100% efficient for the overall repair.

Non-Time (No Operation Number) is labor for which there is no published labor operation or labor time. NON-Time labor operations (often referred to as ‘actual’ or ‘straight’ time) can only be claimed when an applicable labor operation number does not exist in XOT. In instances where an applicable labor operation number does not exist in XOT, labor time(s) for a comparable model should be used.

• Warranty repairs performed that list “No-Operation-Number” ("NON") must be punched and identified separately on the Technician’s Daily Time Ticket to show the actual elapsed time spent on the repair.
  • Labor time requested for NON-Time operations cannot exceed the actual clock punch time specific to the respective repair. Only elapsed time may be claimed.
  • A single NON-Time operation cannot exceed 7 hours. Whenever individual operation codes exist in XOT, they should be claimed.
  • Technician comments must completely support the claimed time. Excessive NON-Time operations are subject to disallowance at MBUSA’s discretion.

• Record the start and finish times of each actual repair, including stop and start times if interrupted.
  • Times are to be rounded to the nearest tenth hour (e.g. 1.24 hours clocked = 1.2 hours claimed, 1.25 hours clocked = 1.3 hours claimed)
  • Dealers that utilize any electronic repair order system: All NON-Time must be identified on the accounting copy and/or warranty copy of the repair order. The dealership must specify the computer applied codes it uses to identify NON-Time.

Note: NON-Time may not be claimed for time spent calling technical hotlines (Unless applicable per state law), prior approval lines, quality control checks or compensation for time lost on a flat rate system. Dealer Technical Bulletins, LIs, Service Campaigns, and Recall Campaigns with NON-Time require a separate time punch, must be identified with proper designation, and must not exceed the specified maximum time allowed.

The Labor Operation Time Guide (XOT) is exclusively for the purpose of computing compensation payable by Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC to its authorized dealers for performance of repairs to Mercedes-Benz vehicles under warranty or other conditions that may be authorized by Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC. The Mercedes-Benz Dealer's Service Manager and warranty personnel must be thoroughly familiar with XOT.
All times published are subject to change based on the establishment of new or revised repair procedures. Labor time is not determined by RO open date or booking date, but by date of submission.

The labor time allowances established in XOT are based on the actual time required to perform the labor operation under normal workshop conditions, with average technician's efficiency, using recommended procedures (WIS instructions), special tools and genuine Mercedes-Benz parts. Time required preparing the vehicle, obtaining the tools and other necessary materials to complete the job as well as a personal allowance are also included. Time allowances do not include time necessary to remove and reinstall special equipment other than Mercedes-Benz options and accessories, nor will MBUSA reimburse the dealer for these additional labor operations.

Comments regarding a particular time allowance can be submitted through the headset icon in all XENTRY applications.

rh:doc.headline: PC 6.3 Fault Code Present - No Problem Found
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 6.3 Fault Code Present - No Problem Found

articles.content: Fault Code Present – No Problem Found diagnostic time reimbursement exists to compensate the dealer when there is a customer complaint, and a fault code is present for the corresponding complaint however, the concern could not be duplicated and no repair was performed. All Fault Code Present – No Problem Found claims are subject to review by MBUSA.

• All XENTRY test data must be submitted via Paperless XD including Freeze Frame data
  • Fault code associated with the customer complaint must be present on Freeze Frame data
  • Fault code must have occurred within 3,000 miles
  • The repair order must document the owner’s complaint
  • MBUSA issued repair procedures must be followed
  • The damage code must identify the component or system which stored the diagnostic code
  • Detailed information must be provided in the dealer text field of the claim

“Fault Code Present – No Problem Found” does not apply:

  • For dealership Add-Ons
  • For claims submitted with incomplete test results (i.e. Freeze frame data missing from Paperless XD)
  • To compensate less skilled technicians for learning
  • For normal vehicle operation or vehicle characteristics
  • For complaints other than the stored fault code in freeze frame data
  • For replacement or repair of parts
  • Outside influence (i.e. bad fuel, gas cap open)
  • To cover non-warranty items (i.e. topping off fluids)
  • For Event Codes
  • For vehicles not covered by the MBUSA New Vehicle Limited Warranty (NVLW)

A qualified technician is expected to run and analyze a Quick Test with Freeze Frame Data to determine whether further diagnosis and/or repairs are necessary.

If after performing a Quick Test and reviewing the freeze frame data, there is a fault code associated with the customer’s complaint, the mileage since the occurrence is less than 3,000 miles, and it is determined that no further diagnosis and/or repairs are necessary, " Fault Code Present – No Problem Found " diagnostic time reimbursement is claimable through a Quick Test (54-1011).

If the determination is further diagnosis through XENTRY guided testing is needed based on the Quick Test and the required freeze frame data, the qualified technician should proceed as prescribed by XENTRY. If the result of the additional guided testing with XENTRY does not lead to a suggested repair, a labor only claim should be submitted by claiming the Quick Test (54-1011) along with the applicable diagnostic operation code(s) for the system being diagnosed.

If the result of the diagnosis is a repair, this would no longer be a Fault Code Present – No Problem Found situation and should be submitted as a repair normally would be according to warranty policies.

Test drives that are required as part of the technical repair procedure may be claimed under warranty/goodwill assuming that they are properly documented and technically justified. Test drives that are performed in conjunction with the service reception and final inspection (e.g quality checks) are considered dealership responsibilities and must not be claimed under warranty.

• Mileage in/out and the time required time in/out when conducting the test drive must be documented on the repair order with a separate time punch for each test drive and be reflected in the technician's story.
  • Reimbursement will only occur if the measurement results confirm the customer complaint.

Examples of test drives that may be claimed under warranty are:

  • Noise inspection drives
  • Measuring drives with test sheet
  • Calibration drives
  • Test drives required by specific workshop documentation

Examples of test-drive claims that may not be claimed under warranty:

  • Compensate less skilled technicians for learning
  • Normal operation or vehicle characteristics
  • Repairs which do not require diagnostic time or road testing
  • Being used as workshop quality check/final inspection or service reception

Generally, for all test drives, fuel used on test drives is not claimable.

Diagnostic/test time for normal service or repair work and identifying symptoms and writing the necessary repair instructions to the technicians, as well as the use of test equipment by the technician, as described in the service literature, is included in the time allowance of the service or repair operation unless listed as a separate operation. Additional time to diagnose unusual service or repair problems other than those listed in XOT that cannot be identified by normal diagnosis is only acceptable when the circumstances are explained in detail on the warranty claim, and are considered necessary by MBUSA or MBUSA’s representatives.
A separate and identifiable punch is required for Diagnostic Time

articles.content: All Group 21 and 99 damage codes can be found in the appropriate group in XOT Local.

Each failure causing part or component requires a separate damage code. Any additional components being replaced which were damaged as a direct result of the primary failed warranted part (primary loss), must have a thorough explanation in the text field and have to be submitted on the same line.

Damage codes that include a right or left location must be used if available. Where several identical component parts (right and left) are replaced as part of a repair (because of a technical specification in WIS,TIPS, etc.), these can then be billed through the damage code for the main damaged part (e.g. suspension strut at left) in a damage instance.

If a damage code is not available for the particular component or repair performed, select the component that would be concerned with the next highest assembly for the repair performed.

Each damage code is made up from the following four distinctive groups of information to make up a complete damage code:

  • Warranty Types: Refers to the first digit of the Damage Code (0 or 1) and determines if the repair is for an original part or spare part
  • Fault Locations: The purpose of the component number is to identify the failure causing part.
  • Fault Types: Obtained directly from the technician’s cause statement noting the nature of the failure.
  • Repair Types: Used to determine the proper repair method for the repair action performed. Repair method can be one of the following:
  • 1 – Major Assembly
  • 7 – Component part replaced
  • 8 – Labor only – no parts used or charged out

Submission of claims with overlapping labor operations are subject to debit. The dealer must make every effort to prevent submitting claims for labor operations that overlap in whole or in part. The included text is only intended to be used as a guide and may not reflect all steps that are necessary to perform a particular repair procedure. Items in the folders are only applicable if required per WIS instructions. To eliminate overlapping labor situations, the dealer should observe WIS Instructions, MBUSA published work procedures, as well as the Group Notes and folders in XOT.

If it is felt that a particular labor operation’s time allowance is insufficient for the necessary work performed and all claimable operations have been applied to the claim, please use the headset feature in XOT or WIS to open an XSF ticket.

The cost of cleaning work will only be accepted if it is required due to significant leaks on components of the vehicle and the soiling has extended beyond the immediate surroundings of the damage location. The cleaning of individual parts and small parts in the workplace as well as the subsequent cleaning of parts is included in the prescribed operation flat rates.

The dealer has responsibilities with respect to service write-up for proper warranty claim submission in regard to warranty repairs and claims. The following must be performed during the Service Write-Up:

  • Verify VMI
  • Identify Repeat Repairs
  • Verify any outstanding Recalls or Campaigns

The servicing dealer is required to establish the vehicle's warranty eligibility and verify the need for the requested repair by reviewing the Vehicle Master Inquiry (VMI) prior to performing any work on the vehicle.

  • The dealer is required to review their internal vehicle history files and the VMI prior to performing any work on the vehicle to identify if the current vehicle complaint is related to a previously performed repair. Repeat or ineffective repairs are not covered under MBUSA's vehicle warranties and subject to disallowance.
  • The completion of outstanding Recalls or Campaigns for an affected vehicle is mandatory.

The following information must be on the repair order:

  • Dealer Name and Address
  • Repair Order Number
  • Owner's Name, Address and Contact Number
  • Year, Make and Model of vehicle
  • Date/Time Vehicle In and Out
  • VIN
  • Mileage In/Mileage Out
  • Repair Order Lines
    • Separate repairs must be listed on separate repair lines
  • Complaint As Stated By Customer or Campaign number as listed on VMI
  • Replacement Part with parts dollar amount (Dealer Net) for each part number
  • Technician story indicating cause and correction with any supporting test data such as Midtronics
  • In the case of a repeat repair, a statement must be included on the second Repair Order stating the following: Same complaint was made on "x" (x = First Repair Order date), R.O. No. xxx (xxx = First Repair Order Number), Repair Group xx and include description of first repair (Example: Thermostat was replaced).
  • Customer Signature: Owner or owner representative signature must be captured (electronic signature acceptable, including Digital Service Drive) at time of initial write-up, prior to repair, after reviewing concerns with customer. Note: The owner representative means only the person who was legally entrusted by the owner to bring the vehicle to the M-B Center for service. If the owner's representative is an employee of the servicing dealer, then the repair order must also be signed by the General Manager, or Service Director/ Manager prior to repairs being performed.
  • Alternate authorizations such as E-Mail, Fax, etc. are acceptable for warranty. Copies of these authorizations must be retained by the dealer and attached to the RO. Any warranty work beyond what is specified in the initial correspondence is considered to be “Add-On Repairs”.
  • If the final invoice contains warranty add-on repairs and/or Goodwill, these repairs must be pointed out to the customer and the customer must sign the customer copy (electronic signature acceptable, including Digital Service Drive) as well as the final invoice to be retained in the service file.
  • Night Drop-off or “Early-Bird”: If an “Early-Bird Drop-Off” envelope has been used by a customer, it is necessary to attach it with the original repair order and retain it in the vehicle service history.
  • Dealer Owned Vehicles: Service Director/Manager must legibly sign repair order on dealer owned vehicles prior to repairs being performed. This would include new, used, demo and rental vehicles. Parts delivery and Service courtesy vehicles are also included.
  • PDI (Pre-Delivery Inspections) are excluded from requiring service management's signature authorizing the repair order.
  • Tow Truck Arrival: The words "Tow In" must be indicated on the repair order. Owner signature or documented telephone confirmation of repair authorization is required prior to beginning repairs.
  • Pick-up and Delivery Service: If a pick-up/delivery service is provided by the dealer, MBUSA recommends that the pick-up/delivery driver take along either Early-Bird envelopes or Pre-Written repair orders and have the owner fill one out and sign it at the time of pick-up. If the dealer employee picking up the vehicle supplies the dealership with verbal work authorization from the customer the employee is considered the owner’s representative and requirements as stated above must be followed.
  • NOTE: For paintwork repairs, a paintwork damage sheet (found in WIS) must be completed and retained in the Vehicle Service History File.

articles.content:
MBUSA pays a base Dealer Parts Handling Rate of 67% for new vehicle warranty repairs for most components (Major assemblies, Goodwill, ELW/CPO and Local Purchases hold different reimbursement rates, review Policy for additional information).

Dealers are permitted to request a Dealer Parts Handling Rate increase once within a 12-month period, unless a different period is provided by state law. It is MBUSA’s preference to review Warranty Part Handling percentage internally with the dealer’s senior management. The intention of this process is to ease the dealer's administrative burden of applying for a Parts Handling rate increase. Of course, MBUSA will accommodate a Dealer that chooses to apply for a Part Handling Rate increase according to a process in the Dealer’s state law, where applicable.

If a dealer has both Passenger Car and Vans franchises, the rate requested should be set based on a combination of both product lines.

There are two processes to request a Dealer Parts Handling rate adjustment.

To submit a proposed parts handling rate for MBUSA’s consideration, a Dealer should submit a "Warranty Part Handling Rate Review Application" through a Star Support case, in accordance with this and all then-current MBUSA policies. Applications must be submitted by Senior Management at the dealership. If the Dealer and MBUSA cannot establish an agreed upon rate, then the Dealer may submit according to its specific state law, where applicable, using the dealer’s own counsel for this guidance.

2. State Law Submission Process: Dealer Senior Management must provide all documentation required under a state statute to request a Dealer Parts Handling Rate increase. Generally, this will require a Parts Handling report along with supporting repair order accounting copies. To apply, submit a “Warranty Parts Handling Rate Review Application” through a Star Support case. A link will be provided to your dealership to submit your supporting documents once your application is received. (As noted below, removable external media such as USB “thumb” drives, cannot be accepted.)

While 3rd parties can and do prepare documents for the dealer, the submission itself must be made from the dealership. Again, we do have a process internally that does not require any third-party involvement; however, it is the dealer’s right to submit a formal package according to the dealer’s state statutes.
  • Packages received including requests on the dealer’s behalf to engage 3rd party companies with removable media such as USB’s or links to cloud storage are not permitted by MBUSA policy.

articles.content: MBUSA will establish a reasonable Warranty Labor Rate for a new dealership as determined by a MBUSA verified competitive market survey. The dealership, after six (6) full months of operation, can then apply for a Warranty Labor Rate adjustment as outlined in the Warranty Labor Rate Review Process of this manual.

Before applying for a warranty labor rate increase, the dealer must:

  • Establish a reasonable retail owner labor rate. A reasonable retail owner labor rate is one which is consistent with sound and competitive business practices associated with other competitive franchised automotive dealers in the dealer's local geographic area of service responsibility.
  • MBUSA considers the following manufacturers to be direct competitors that should be evaluated: Audi, BMW, Infiniti, Jaguar, Land Rover, Lexus, Porsche and Volvo.
Before applying for labor rate increase same rules will apply as stated in the Warranty Labor Rate Review Process.

rh:doc.headline: PC 4.2 Warranty Labor Rate Approved

articles.content: MBUSA will review Warranty Labor Rate increase requests once within a 12-month period, unless otherwise governed by applicable law for a dealership. The process is initiated by the dealer via the Warranty Labor Rate system accessible through NetStar. The period of 12 months is based on the previous labor rate increase effective date. Labor rate changes are effective on the 1st of every month following final approved decision.

Before applying for a warranty labor rate increase, the dealer must:

  • Establish a reasonable retail owner labor rate. A reasonable retail owner labor rate is one which is consistent with sound and competitive business practices associated with other competitive franchise automotive dealers in the dealer's local geographic area of service responsibility.
  • MBUSA considers the following manufacturers to be direct competitors that should be evaluated: Audi, BMW, Infiniti, Jaguar, Land Rover, Lexus, Porsche and Volvo.

Dealers may choose to study competitive retail labor rates in their local geographic area prior to implementing or changing the retail labor rate. This study must include other competitive franchised automotive dealers.

  • Represent a change in their market conditions (market increase) that would merit an increase in warranty labor rate to remain competitive within their market. If no market conditions have changed, as verified by an MBUSA Competitive Market Survey (performed by a MBUSA contracted third-party affiliate), MBUSA reserves the right not to grant an increase in warranty labor rate unless otherwise governed by local / state regulations..
  • Inform MBUSA if market conditions cause a decrease in their retail labor rate, so their warranty labor rate can be adjusted accordingly.
  • Maintain a reasonable percentage of warranty labor sales to the retail labor sales as determined by the MBUSA Regional average. This ratio is monitored by the MBUSA Field Representative.
  • MBUSA has no explicit signage or repair order posting requirement. MBUSA’s belief is that service-pricing disclosure is sound business practice and MBUSA encourages dealers to post their retail labor rate, or to provide their owners with service estimates. Posting of the retail labor rate helps to eliminate the questions over service pricing and many associated owner concerns. MBUSA suggests that the dealer consult their attorney for the best method of disclosure for compliance with any applicable state and local laws.

Dealers are permitted to request a Warranty Labor Rate increase once within a 12-month period, unless otherwise governed by local / state regulations. MBUSA will reimburse warranty labor at a reasonable rate in accordance with applicable law. MBUSA may consider average labor rate the dealer regularly charges its own customers for retail service labor (Effective Labor Rate) as determined by the dealer’s dealer management system (DMS). The rate of reimbursement will not exceed the calculated customer pay labor rate.

The intention of this labor rate process is to ease the dealer's administrative burden of applying for a labor rate increase. MBUSA will accommodate a dealer that chooses to apply for a labor rate per their state law.

Note for dealers using a 3rd party to prepare Warranty Labor Rate requests.

Labor rate requests must be submitted by the dealership. While 3rd parties can and do prepare documents for the dealer, the submission itself must be made from the dealership.

Packages received including requests on the dealer’s behalf to engage 3rd party companies with removable media such as USB’s or links to cloud storage are not permitted by MBUSA policy.

Please see removable media NCU below

Contact for labor rate questions: 171-warrantylaborrate.pool-id@mbusa.com

Dealers must submit a "Warranty Labor Rate Review Application" available online via NetStar, in accordance with the provisions of the terms of the Mercedes-Benz Dealer Agreements and all the current MBUSA policies. Applications must be submitted via NetStar in a complete / correct status.

The dealer must submit a “Dealer Management System Labor Rate Report”, also known as an Effective Labor Rate report, showing that the dealer is effectively charging their customers the requested warranty labor rate. There is no requirement for this report to be created from a DMS (Dealer Management System), only that the report accurately reports the information according to MB policy or applicable state law. This report is the basis for the rate request. It is ultimately the Dealer’s responsibility to produce an accurate report.

See Supplementary Documents for a helpful Labor Rate FAQ

Passenger Cars and Commercial Vans are separate franchises with their own respective labor rates. Any reporting must be purely Passenger car or purely Vans and may not be mixed. No other manufacturers may be included in these reports.

The report must encompass the lesser of:

  • 100 sequential customer paid repair orders

*OR*

  • 90 days of sequential customer paid repair orders
  • Do not remove, black out or cross off any date or repair information and include all labor operations, sale types, sale amounts and dates of Repair Orders.
  • Repairs discounted with manufacturer promotional discounts or specials may be excluded from the Repair order sample to establish rates unless otherwise specified by applicable law.
  • Discounts not itemized on the Repair Order as parts or labor must be allocated based on total cost. The excel worksheet offered below is an option for an ELR that does not calculate discounts due to this type of invoicing.
  • Exclude all internal repair orders.
  • Exclude all 3rd party paid repairs (e.g. Aftermarket Warranty, goodwill, Insurance)
  • Exclude Tires replaced for general wear
  • Exclude all discounted factory routine maintenance services and any other service/repairs excluded by state law: MBUSA defines routine maintenance as the required items that have specific time / mileage intervals published on the factory maintenance sheets (Service A/B). Excluded services beyond our published, scheduled routine maintenance must be specifically stated in your state law as an exclusion
    • An important note on unilaterally excluded labor codes: If excluding entire opcodes from the report (e.g. alignments, brakes, keys, etc.) you must separate qualified from not-qualified repairs. If qualified repairs are omitted from the calculation the application will be rejected.
  • ELR must report
    • Grand total for ELR
    • ELR calculation for qualified repairs on each RO
    • Repair Order number
    • Invoice Date of each RO reported
    • Hours sold on qualified repairs of each RO
    • Retail dollars sold for qualified repairs on each RO
    • Discount applied and allocated for qualified repairs on each RO
    • Retail dollars minus discount sold on qualified repairs of each RO

Ultimately it is the dealer’s responsibility to produce a compliant report out of their own selected DMS; however we have a basic Excel sheet available in supplementary Documents below that may be filled in as an option to provide an alternative.

Note: This excel sheet must be converted to a .pdf before attaching to an application.

The instructions for running this report are outlined in the Supplementary Documents under Labor Rate Request.

It is a recommendation that dealers not submit a request of Warranty Labor Rate increase immediately after they have increased their Retail Labor Rate. DMS reports will not reflect the increase in the Effective Labor Rate and will not allow for an MBUSA approved increase. We recommend waiting six (6) months after increasing the Retail Labor Rate for best possible application submission.

MBUSA will notify the dealer via e-mail informing when the change in warranty rate has been approved and becomes effective. MBUSA reserves the right to reject an increase in Warranty Labor Rate in its sole business discretion subject to applicable law.

Under the terms of the MBUSA New Vehicle Limited Warranty, in-stock vehicles, which have not been sold to a retail purchaser or have not been registered for demonstrator or company use, carry the following stipulations.

  • Warranty period starts from date of registration or in-service date but no later than 18 months from vehicle production date. Coverage will be adjusted to reflect the actual warranty period start.
  • Vehicle is not warranted beyond 500 miles
  • Company (Consigned) vehicles sold to dealers are warranted for the unexpired portion of the original warranty

  • Vehicles where the in service date cannot be substantiated will be calculated as follows:
    • 1 month in service for every 1,000 miles on the odometer.

The dealer must make the date that the vehicle was placed in service (which is also the warranty start date) clear to the retail customer. This is to avoid any misunderstanding between the customer and the dealer since only the unexpired portion of the original warranty is passed on to the retail customer. Check applicable state laws for any exceptions.

As stated in the Mercedes-Benz Passenger Car Dealer Agreement, and the Mercedes-Benz Light Truck Dealer Agreement, MBUSA through its employees and other designees, reserves the right to adopt, and from time to time, to change the procedures necessary to periodically examine authorized Mercedes-Benz Dealership facilities, records, accounts, and all Mercedes-Benz products on hand.

• MBUSA supports the sale of Mercedes-Benz vehicles and parts with various reimbursements/payments to authorized Mercedes-Benz dealers. These various reimbursements and payments to authorized Mercedes-Benz dealers require that the authorized Mercedes-Benz dealer adhere to specific qualifying actions and conditions.
  • MBUSA reserves the right to periodically perform, during regular business hours, on-site dealership warranty audits to:
    • Adequately monitor and approve the warranty repairs that are performed by the dealership.
    • Validate the warranty claims submitted by the dealership to MBUSA.
    • Validate goodwill.

The MBUSA Warranty Audit Team uses a three-pronged Warranty Audit approach to focus on:

1.Confirming the dealership’s compliance with MBUSA Warranty Manual requirements.

2.Evaluating the dealership’s expense trends.

3.Identifying the dealership’s out-of-line Warranty conditions and addressing/correcting identified out-of-line Warranty conditions as early as possible.

  • The Dealer must provide assistance to the MBUSA Warranty Audit Team in such matters as locating, interpreting and analyzing the dealer’s claims, paper work and control documentation.
  • As stated in the Mercedes-Benz Passenger Car Dealer Agreement, Smart, and the Mercedes-Benz Light Truck Dealer Agreement, dealerships must provide the MBUSA Warranty Audit Team with any and all documents requested by the Warranty Audit Team.
  • When a dealer is notified of a Warranty Audit, the dealer must comply promptly and fully with the Warranty Audit related directives given to the dealer by the MBUSA Warranty Department and by the MBUSA Warranty Audit Team.
  • Failure to maintain adequate documentation will result in a chargeback. MBUSA may take such other actions, as MBUSA deems appropriate.
  • Dealers are required to provide the MBUSA Warranty Audit Team with:
    • A Dealer designated management employee to work with the MBUSA Warranty Audit Team in gathering/obtaining necessary dealership records.
    • A conference room or similar work area that can accommodate 4-6 persons and their electronic equipment.
    • EDS (Electronic Document Storage) dealers must supply terminals and a dedicated printer.

Dealer Selection Criteria

  • Overall KPI Warranty Scorecard and Ranking
  • Specific categories out of range (hours, parts and frequency)
  • Field and management requests
  • Information concerning fraudulent actions and practices
  • Specific damages out of line vs. the national average
  • Normal evolution / progression
  • Red dealers previously audited
  • Time since last review

Appeal Process

  • The Dealer must request a formal review, in writing, of the Warranty Audit results by the MBUSA Warranty Audit Department. The Dealer’s formal review request must be received by the MBUSA Warranty Audit Department by the Appeal Deadline outlined in the Warranty Audit Report. The Dealer must supply all supporting pertinent documents, such as Repair Order shop/hard copies and excel spreadsheets to the MBUSA Warranty Audit Department.
  • If the Dealer does request a review by the MBUSA Warranty Audit Department, the final Warranty Audit results will be communicated to the Dealer by a Final Review notification. It is critical that your dealership provide the most complete information so that MBUSA is able to understand your position when reviewing your appeal. Once the appeal decision is made and communicated, it will be deemed as final and no additional appeal will be accepted.
  • If no communication is received by the MBUSA Warranty Audit Department from the Dealer by the Appeal deadline, then MBUSA Warranty Audit Department will presume the Dealer has consented to the results of the audit contained in the initial Warranty Audit Report.

Debits
The Warranty Audit is considered final and any audit chargeback / debited claims are recorded on the R22 report and will appear on the dealers consolidated parts statement.

State Statute Debit Limitations: Some states have statutes on warranty. MBUSA will follow all applicable laws with respect to debit limits and requirements. In addition, dealership staff should be familiar with the legislation in their respective state and consult their own legal counsel to determine their entitlements or responsibilities under these laws.

MBUSA provides weekly information through NetStar Warranty Scorecard targeting specific claims paid. Service Management is responsible for reviewing and monitoring the scorecard and implementing corrective action as needed.

These claims are available for the dealer to review and take action where necessary or provide additional explanation.

  • MBUSA provides dealers with Warranty Key Performance Indicators (KPI’s) via NetStar reports.

The Repair Order (RO) is a legal document that must accurately reflect the technician’s work on each vehicle. All technicians are required to record complete and truthful labor time for every repair line, including warranty, customer pay work, and internal. Time recording requirements apply to all employees involved in performing any repair.

Mercedes-Benz AG’s hybrid time guide combines flat-rate allowances with actual technician time spent on repairs. This structure requires that time punches reflect genuine, active engagement with the vehicle. Time entries that appear to be extended without corresponding repair activity—such as prolonged idle time or running time without documented work—may be considered a misrepresentation of labor effort. MBUSA considers such discrepancies a serious breach of timekeeping standards.

MBUSA reserves the right to audit and challenge any claim that lacks sufficient documentation or cannot be reasonably substantiated. Patterns of inflated or unverifiable time entries may be escalated for further review

Note: It is expected that time recording during a repair logically align with time stamped supporting documentation. Repairs that cannot be reviewed according to the supplied documentation will be subject (whole or in-part) to debit.

Time recording method / documentation must be consistent for all warranty, customer pay and internal repair orders and contain the following information.

  • Technicians may not have time recorded on more than one repair or repair order at the same time.
  • The full date and time for all repairs must be accurately and logically recorded on the repair order.
  • The industry standard for technician efficiency is 125%. Claims that exceed this standard will be reviewed for reasonableness and feasibility and will be subject to debit if found to be excessive.
  • The repairing technician's identification number
  • Actual start and end (“on” and “off”) times
  • DMS (Dealer Management System) time recording must be consistent and identifiable
  • The related repair order number and line item
  • A separate and identifiable punch is required for Diagnostic Time and NON-Time
  • Documentation of reasonable elapsed time to perform all repairs must be evident and reported accurately and supported by time punching and payroll records
  • The original copy of technician’s three (3) piece daily time ticket or other paper recording device must be retained to support the claim and kept in the Vehicle History File.
  • Any time spent on non-automotive repair functions, must be identified and documented by time punching and payroll records.
  • Perforated sticker (top copy) from technician’s daily time ticket must be affixed to the back of the shop copy at the completion of the repair.
  • Any changes to the recording of technician's time including Date, Start, Finish, Duration, Type, Tech, Line or any other portion of recorded Technician Time requires Service Management authorization and must include initials, date/time of authorization and reason for change.

Mobile service repairs must adhere to time recording requirements as stated above. Additionally, the method used in your dealership to track a technician’s time must be used on mobile service.

Express Service:

  • Dealer must have a consistent process to track team based time records for Express Service Program.
  • High efficiency on Express Service Program due to a team based system is acceptable.
  • Refer to Express Service by Mercedes Benz Program Guide
To facilitate claim review, product improvement and validation of repairs performed, dealers must utilize the Paperless XD system whenever the XENTRY system is used.
