  • Failure to submit XENTRY captured test results / information via the Paperless XD system may lead to debit of any warranty claims either in whole or in part at the discretion of MBUSA.
  • Paper or scanned copies of XENTRY printouts will not be accepted in lieu of missing electronic submission of XENTRY test results / information.

• Paperless XD information must be submitted while performing each repair (customer pay, internal, and warranty).

Note: State and federal laws may require dealers to retain certain documents for longer durations and/or may require that dealers retain physical copies of the XENTRY printout. Please contact your local council to ensure compliance with local laws.

Each dealer must keep up-to-date vehicle service history files (either Paper or Electronic not both) on each vehicle it sells and services for all warranty, customer-pay, internal or service contract repairs. These files are to be maintained by the vehicle identification number of the service vehicle with a cross-reference to the owner’s name. These files must be readily available.

Files must include:

  • PDI forms (Note: PDI printed forms are only required for VINs prior to launch of e-PDI tool.)

  • Final accounting copies
  • Any and all related test results unable to be uploaded to pXD must be retained in the service file (alignment sheet, Midtronics test results, before/after specs, etc.). Certain test printouts may become illegible overtime, it is recommend that the documents be scanned or a photo copy be retained with the vehicle service history file.

  • Any other records which support claims reimbursed by MBUSA
  • Copies of any vehicle inspection reports performed on the vehicle whether charged to the customer, internally, or for no charge.

The system must:

This section provides information on what records should be stored at the dealership. Files must be maintained entirely in that format. When a sales agreement is terminated after a claim has been submitted or a repair has been performed, there are provisions for submitting warranty claims.

MBUSA asks dealers to submit claims as soon as possible, but no later than State Statue requires, of the vehicle repair date. However, when a “Buy/Sell” agreement or any other form of termination of the Dealer Agreement(s) occurs, and claims are generated prior to termination and are being processed, MBUSA keeps the Selling/Terminating dealer’s account open for one hundred twenty (120) days from the official termination date.

• It is the sole responsibility of the selling/terminated dealer to retain all necessary documentation and parts (according to MBUSA policy at the time) to support any warranty work performed but not finalized at the time of termination.
  • The selling/terminated dealer must submit warranty repairs according to all applicable Warranty Policies and Procedures.
Technician responsibilities are to be supervised by Service Management.

• Documentation of technician name and number on repair order are required for each respective repair. (All technicians assigned to a repair must be documented separately and entered accordingly on claim.) If a team, group or lateral support structure is used, each repairing technician must be identified and clocked separately. (Refer to Policy 3.5 Time Recording for additional information.)

• Verification of initial vehicle mileage to ensure repair order mileage is correct.
  • Documentation of diagnostic, repair, test drive, and final repair completion mileage.
  • Capture XENTRY test results/information via the Paperless XD system.
  • Noting Add-on repairs as such on repair order.
  • Repairs are to be performed per the latest technical information (e.g. via the WIS and TIPS system); however this information does not constitute an extension of existing warranty coverage unless otherwise stated.
  • ONLY the technician that performed the repair must enter an accurate, complete description of the repair on the repair order which:
    • Identifies the cause and correction that resolved the complaint providing only details necessary to support labor operations being claimed.
    • Identifies replaced parts (number & quantity)

Service Management has certain responsibilities in regard to warranty claims and repairs. MBUSA considers the Parts & Service Director, Service Director, Service Manager, Shop Foreman or Group/Team Leader as members of Service Management.

Dealer Service Management responsibilities include:

  • Supervision over all Service operations and its employees.
  • Apply controls to eliminate unnecessary, improper, or over-repair.
  • Supervise all MBUSA paid warranty claims, including complete and accurate claim preparation.
  • Ensure accurate technician time recording.
  • Approving handwritten labor time entries.
  • Signing repair orders for dealer owned vehicles. This would include new, used, demo and rental vehicles. Parts delivery and Service courtesy vehicles are also included.
  • Tracking and monitoring technician efficiency and productivity.
  • Monitoring Goodwill repairs.
  • Monitoring Add-on repairs.
  • Ensure that repairs are performed by technicians that are properly trained to perform the specific repairs.
  • Ensure that repairs on any Mercedes-Benz Hybrid or Electric vehicle are performed by technicians that are properly trained and have successfully completed the required courses or MBUSA equivalent course for power down, etc. If not available, an FSE must be present to perform power down process.
  • If required by MBUSA, the Service Manager (or higher level of management) must pre-authorize repairs on the repair order prior to work being performed. The initials of the Service Manager (or higher level of management), time, and date must be recorded on the line. Additionally the acronym “SMA” should be recorded to denote the pre-authorization of the repair.

The following are non-inclusive examples of areas subject to review and disallowance:

  • Date or Mileage Alteration
  • VIN or Owner Misrepresentation
  • Used Vehicle Reconditioning
  • Repeat or Ineffective Repair
  • Any Supporting Documentation Unavailable
  • Non-Mercedes Parts Claimed as Genuine
  • Part Damaged, Not Defective
  • Phone approval, on-site inspector approval, video imaging approval or Technical Hotline involvement with a repair does not absolve the dealership of its responsibilities to adhere to the provisions of this Warranty Manual.
  • Such approval does not exempt the repair from being subject to MBUSA review or audit.
Dealership personnel are responsible for up-holding warranty policy and procedures within this Warranty Manual as well as all warranty bulletins.

Responsibilities Include:

  • Obtaining a detailed explanation of the complaint from the customer.
  • Verifying warranty coverages. A check of the VMI (Vehicle Master Inquiry) must be performed to verify warranty start date, history of repairs and special statuses.
  • Checking for physical abuse/damage that may pertain to customer’s complaint.
  • Verify correct mileage on the vehicle at time of write-up.
  • Obtain customer's signature authorizing repairs prior to work being performed.
  • Compliance with regard to the validation, preparation, submission, accounting and the keeping of records on all warranty claims.

The Goodwill policy authorization is granted to all dealers that comply with the Mercedes-Benz Goodwill requirements. Individual dealers will be subject to suspension and/or removal from this Goodwill policy if they fail to adhere to the policy and MBUSA's expectations. Goodwill may be extended for repairs that are not covered by an MBUSA warranty. Goodwill offers must not exceed 50% of the current market value, in a repaired state, of the vehicle as indicated in a commercial retail pricing guide at time of repair (ex: KBB, Edmonds). There are no restrictions to dollar amount (other than the 50% market value of the vehicle), mileage, and/or time in service under the Goodwill policy. Refer to Policy 7.6 Field Authorization for instances which may require prior Field Representative approval. As it applies to the policy, each Goodwill adjustment consideration must be decided individually and on the merits of the situation. There is never an obligation to offer Goodwill to the customer. Any discretionary Goodwill offer does not represent any recognition or obligation by the manufacturer.

Note: When offering an MBUSA PPM or ELW contract, it must be billed out at no more than MSRP on the dealer goodwill claim.

At least two people (Service Management) in each dealership must be designated to determine Goodwill adjustments. These designated dealership staff are responsible for owner satisfaction and must have authority to offer dealer funds toward that goal.

  • The owner must be informed by the dealer of the Goodwill offer and its amount.
    • The Goodwill offer must be clearly typed and identified on all copies of the repair order including the customer copy
      • Example: Goodwill offered to the customer and customer accepted 50% labor Customer, 50% labor MBUSA, Parts 50% Customer, 50% MBUSA, DH to be covered by dealer.
      • Example: Goodwill offered to the customer and accepted. Customer paying for engine and fluids, MBUSA to cover all labor and an alternator, Dealer is covering 50% of DH.
    • If the final invoice contains warranty add-on repairs and/or Goodwill, these repairs must be pointed out to the customer and the customer must sign the customer copy (electronic signature acceptable, including Digital Service Drive) as well as the final invoice to be retained in the service file. For pick-up and Delivery Service vehicles, please refer to Service Write-up. Many states will require that these signatures are obtained on all documents. You should consult with your local counsel and/or state authorities to be certain of the requirements.
    • Claims where the associated Repair Order do not meet this requirement are subject to debit.
  • Repairs must be performed according to standard Mercedes-Benz repair procedures.
  • The owner must receive the benefit of the adjustment immediately. If the owner is not satisfied with the Goodwill offer, Goodwill must be withdrawn.
  • Dealers are only required to submit the parts and/or labor operations for which reimbursement is being requested under technical goodwill.
    • If any parts or labor operations are being reimbursed as a percentage, the full cost of those parts or labor must be billed on the claim, with the appropriate percentage applied to reflect the goodwill portion.
      Examples:
      • A 75/25 split: submit the full claim and adjust the percentages to reflect the split
      • Customer pays all labor: submit only the parts being requested for goodwill
      • Dealer is offering goodwill of one part and all the labor; customer pays for another part: submit all labor operations and the one part under goodwill
  • All goodwill claims must include clear documentation of the repair being performed, regardless of how it is being claimed. This includes proper time punches and a breakdown of manufacturer, dealer, and customer contributions.
  • Goodwill policy adjustments are NOT to be offered or provided if:
    • The owner will not be satisfied.
    • The vehicle condition or lack of required maintenance or maintenance records directly relates to the concern.
    • Beyond 50% of the current market value of the vehicle at the time of repair.
    • The damage is outside influence (example: accident damage) or items that should be claimed through insurance.

Participation is any dollar contribution made by the dealership and/or the customer towards the cost of repair

  • Customer participation is not always mandatory (but strongly encouraged)
  • Forfeiting dealer handling is not mandatory.
  • Dealer participation is not required on every goodwill claim, however MBUSA expects that the dealership will overall contribute a meaningful portion to enhance the program’s effectiveness. Dealer’s participation can be tracked via the Warranty Scorecard.

Technical Goodwill participation does not mean compensation outside of the actual repair costs, for example: Loaner Vehicles, gift cards, accessories, detailing the customer's vehicle, etc.

Note: Dealer contribution toward Goodwill Repairs CANNOT be considered the difference between warranty and customer pay rate.

Note: Parts replaced under DSA/Goodwill carry the full Mercedes-Benz Spare Parts warranty.

The following conditions are EXCLUDED from the Dealer Goodwill Program:

  • Goodwill funds cannot be used for vehicles in dealer, broker, wholesaler or finance company inventory.
  • The vehicle must be in the possession of the ultimate owner.
  • Technical Goodwill funds cannot be used to buy-back vehicles, provide trade assist, pay for lease payments, buy flowers, dinner, gifts, etc. Contact your Field Representative regarding these customer retention situations. (Refer to Policy 5.4 Special MBUSA Damage Codes for relative damage codes.)
  • Reconditioning of used vehicles is not permitted.
  • Not applicable if the vehicle is covered by a third party extended warranty, insurance policy, service contract, or similar plan. Note: Vehicles covered by a CPO or ELW contract are eligible for the goodwill program as these extended warranties are not considered to be third party.
  • A Goodwill claim cannot be used to cover parts sold but not installed by an authorized Mercedes-Benz dealer.
  • Goodwill funds cannot be applied to any comebacks, unsuccessful, or failed repair attempts. Comebacks, unsuccessful or failed repair attempts are the responsibility of the dealership.
  • Goodwill adjustments for MBUSA, dealer employees and relatives (members of the immediate family) are not covered under this Goodwill policy. Such situations must be determined by the Field Representative.
  • Any claim that was not originally submitted as Goodwill cannot be resubmitted as Goodwill.
  • Grey Market Vehicles.
  • A Vehicle Master Inquiry (VMI) must be performed to determine if the vehicle is eligible under these guidelines. Vehicles with an entry in the “Status Needs Authorization” field are not eligible for Goodwill.
  • Any vehicle with a 2, 3, 9, T or R status indicator.
  • Goodwill is not intended to replace dealer policy.
  • Goodwill funds are not intended to cover suggested customer pay repairs that the customer later declined.
  • Goodwill funds are not intended for No Problem Found claims (i.e. showing the customers how to use features/functions/options on vehicle, normal operations of vehicles, etc.)

Refer to Field Authorization Requirements for repairs which require prior Field Representative Approval.

Any individual warranty repair found necessary, but not originally requested by the customer are considered add-on repairs., Repairs to any unit in dealer inventory (new, Pre-owned, lease turn-in, loaner, delivery vehicle, etc.) are considered add-ons and are subject to this policy.

Each dealership is responsible for monitoring the number of add-on repairs being performed by their employees and should maintain a process in-house for doing so. It is the dealership's responsibility to ensure that such repairs were qualified and necessary prior to claim submission. As part of the normal claiming process, all Add-on repairs should be identified as such by checking the add-on indicator box located in EVA under "Additional Damage Information".

Note: For warranty purposes, if the repair order is signed, MBUSA does not require the customer’s signature on the final invoice unless the invoice contains warranty add-on repairs and/or Goodwill. If the final invoice contains warranty add-on repairs, and/or Goodwill, these repairs must be pointed out to the customer and the customer must sign the customer copy (electronic signature acceptable, including Digital Service Drive) as well as the final invoice to be retained in the service file. For Pick-up and Delivery Service vehicles, please refer to Policy 5.1 Service Write Up. Many states will require that these signatures are obtained on all documents. You should consult with your local counsel and/or state authorities to be certain of the requirements.

Note: If there is abuse of the add-on repair policy, MBUSA reserves the right to restrict or prohibit dealers from performing add-on repairs, except for service campaigns, recalls or items seriously affecting the operational safety of the vehicle.

MBUSA recommends that each dealership's process for monitoring add-on repairs includes a method to check the necessity of said repairs (e.g. an internal approval process). MBUSA provides a Warranty Scorecard via NetStar for each dealership to use. It is recommended that the "Damages Per Visit" KPI is monitored regularly to help track add-on repairs. MBUSA will regularly monitor the Warranty Scorecard for deviations at individual dealerships. Deviations could result in actions including but not limited to: claim review, warranty audits, parts inspections, removal of add-on privileges, etc.

Warranty repairs must be checked in order to verify that they are completed to the owner’s satisfaction. Dealers are responsible for the proper completion of warranty work. This final quality control inspection is considered the dealer's responsibility to ensure customer satisfaction and cannot be claimed under warranty.

• Specific quality control procedures must be established by each dealer.
  • Qualified personnel must inspect and check vehicles when the warranty repair is completed to ensure that all the owner’s warrantable concerns were corrected.
  • Whenever necessary, vehicles must be road tested; road tests for quality control cannot be claimed under warranty.

• Dealer is responsible for any repair that:
    • Is not properly accomplished
    • Consists of unnecessary repairs
    • Is due to a shop comeback
    • Is a result of improper diagnosis
      • Any costs arising from this must not be charged to either the Mercedes-Benz national organization or the customer.
      • If a vehicle returns to a dealer other than the original repairing dealer and requires subsequent work to correct the customer's condition because of one of these reasons, then the cost for the subsequent repair work is subject to chargeback to the original repairing dealer. Contact your Field Representative to discuss the findings prior to starting the repair. The second repairing dealer should submit for reimbursement as warranty, and the chargeback to the original repairing dealer will be accomplished via the Miscellaneous Billing System and will be reflected on the consolidated parts statement.

Note: The chargeback amount will be determined in conjunction with the QEC and will be communicated to the dealer following parts inspection.

  • Claims will be rejected by MBUSA if there is evidence of improper performance of service work.

Dealers that charge visiting owners for warrantable repairs are in violation of Federal law and their Mercedes-Benz Dealer Agreement. Visiting owner policy - All authorized Mercedes-Benz dealers must provide prompt and courteous service to visiting owners.

Dealers should make their customers aware of service requirements:

  • Periodic Servicing - Owner must be aware of the service requirements listed in the Service and Warranty Information Booklet.
  • Warranty Service - It is the responsibility of the owner to PROVE and of the dealer to JUDGE whether the required maintenance service has been performed.
  • Notice of pre-owned vehicle purchase - Owner should be advised entitled to unused portion of unexpired original NVLW.
  • Change of address - MBUSA must be notified immediately of an owner's address change to ensure that the distributor is in a position to notify the owner of any corrections to the vehicle that may become necessary.

Warranty Service Requirements: When an owner requests service or repairs work on a vehicle under warranty, the owner must provide the dealer with evidence that the service requirements listed in the Service and Warranty Information Booklet have been complied with.

Any repair work performed under warranty due to a manufacturing defect must be performed at an MBUSA Certified Collision Center. Damage or malfunctions caused by body repairs not performed in accordance with Mercedes-Benz specified repair procedures or otherwise not properly performed are not covered by this warranty.

Please visit the Mercedes-Benz Certified Collision Program for additional details

Due to the innovative assembly procedures and materials used in the production of all Mercedes-Benz models, it is strongly recommended that any body repair (collision damage, corrosion, and repair/paintwork) be performed by a body shop recommended by MBUSA. These body shops are the only facilities that MBUSA has certified as qualified to perform such repairs since they are equipped with trained personnel using tools, equipment, and paint products authorized by Mercedes-Benz.

rh:doc.headline: PC 3.10 Accidents, Property Damage, Personal Injury and Fires
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 3.10 Accidents, Property Damage, Personal Injury and Fires

articles.content:
In the event of an accident, property damage, injury, or fire that is allegedly caused by a Mercedes-Benz product, certain actions must be taken.

It is the responsibility of all Mercedes-Benz Dealerships to notify MBUSA (Market Team/CAC) immediately when any Mercedes-Benz product is alleged to have caused accidents, property damage, personal injury or fires.

In the event of an accident, property damage, injury, or fire that is allegedly caused by a Mercedes-Benz product, certain actions must be taken.

Mercedes-Benz Dealership personnel must not take any action or make any statement regarding a claim with respect to injuries or defect while an inspection is pending or during the pendency of any subsequent claim resolution. Such actions or comments may be misconstrued as being positions taken on behalf of the Mercedes-Benz Dealership or MBUSA when they in fact are not.

In the event of an accident, property damage, injury, or fire that is allegedly caused by a Mercedes-Benz product, certain actions must be taken.

The vehicle or parts involved in any situation involving personal injury or death or involving allegations of defect must be completely preserved by being protected from the elements, kept all in one place and clearly labeled for reliable identification and stored in a secure location for protection from theft, manipulation and vandalism.

rh:doc.headline: PC 3.9 Damaged, Altered or Total Loss Vehicle Reporting
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 3.9 Damaged, Altered or Total Loss Vehicle Reporting

articles.content: MBUSA requires all dealers to provide notification of any non-sold vehicle in dealer inventory that has sustained significant damage. Vehicles presented for service are also subject to this requirement. Vehicles, which have been altered or modified, should be reported to your Field Representative. If safety is impaired by the modification, the customer must be notified of possible risks in writing.

If a Status needs to be applied to the vehicle, contact your Field Represetnative. New Vehicle Limited Warranty is subject to be voided or partially voided by MBUSA on vehicles identified as having sustained significant damage with the exception of Federal and California Emissions Warranties. Vehicles deported outside the United States, scrapped, dismantled, rebuilt or stolen are also subject to this action.

Warranty coverage on vehicles converted to limousines and convertibles, or on other than U.S.A. version vehicles which have been altered to allegedly meet safety or emission standards must be viewed in the context of the type of change made to the vehicle.

If the conversion creates technical problems, those difficulties would be considered as owner expense. The warranty would also be void on those individual components which were altered to allegedly meet safety or emission standards. Components unaffected by the conversion or alteration would continue to be covered by the terms of any applicable MBAG or MBUSA warranties that have been issued to the owner of the vehicle.

The dealer is required to administer warranty and policy repair service in accordance with the provisions of the Sales and Service Agreement, MBUSA’s Warranty Statements, this manual and applicable state and local franchise laws.

rh:doc.headline: PC 2.7 Vehicles of the Armed Forces (Overseas Purchase)
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 2.7 Vehicles of the Armed Forces (Overseas Purchase)

articles.content: Vehicles sold to the armed forces have specific criteria for warranty coverage. The owner of such a vehicle is entitled to the extended Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC warranty of 48 months or 50,000 miles, whichever occurs first, if certain criteria are met.

• The vehicle must be purchased from an authorized Mercedes-Benz dealer or through a Military Post Exchange Order.
  • The vehicle was manufactured to conform to the USA Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards and Emission Regulations applicable at the time of manufacture. (A corresponding certification label is affixed to the left "B" pillar post of all vehicles in which U.S. equipment is installed.)
  • The vehicle is driven in the United States or Puerto Rico. In all other countries the vehicle is covered by the applicable country's limited warranty.

Warranty applicable to Military Vehicles:

  • 4 year/50,000 miles, whichever event occurs first. Starts the day of the bill of sale and is honored in Germany and in the USA.
  • Tires have their own warranty from the manufacturer.
  • Roadside assistance is only honored in the USA, but will take effect when the customer goes back to the USA.
  • Extended warranty needs to be purchased within the 1st year of owning the vehicle, however, can be purchased only at a dealership in the USA and is only valid in the USA.

When these requirements are met, the dealer may proceed with repairs under the warranty in accordance with the policies and procedures in this manual. The vehicle’s owner will be issued a Service and Warranty Information Booklet. The owner must be advised to register the vehicle immediately in writing with a copy of the factory invoice and production card at the following address:

Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC
13470 International Parkway
Jacksonville, FL 32218
Attn.: Warranty Services

rh:doc.headline: PC 2.6 Vehicles Not Purchased through MBUSA (Grey Market or Traveling in the USA)
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: PC 2.6 Vehicles Not Purchased through MBUSA (Grey Market or Traveling in the USA)

articles.supplementarytopicstitle: PC 7.5 Spare Parts and Over The Counter Parts Warranty

articles.content:
All vehicles not purchased from or through MBUSA, may have the applicable country's New Vehicle Limited Warranty. The selling source of a vehicle must always be determined from documents presented by the owner before any warranty work is handled. Coverage must be checked in EVA prior to performing any repairs on these vehicles.

The owner must be informed that:

  • Parts may not be readily available
  • MBUSA may not have the technical information for service and repair of such vehicles

Grey Market Vehicles

  • Have the DAG World-Wide Warranty coverage of 24 months/unlimited mileage.
  • Qualify for Sign and Drive, however, they do not qualify for Roadside Assistance
  • Qualify for Spare Parts Warranty coverage.
  • Certain market specific contracts or warranties cannot be covered in the US (such as ELW/CPO/PPM)
  • Warranty claims for exported CKD/SKD (knockdown) vehicles/major assemblies are to be addressed to the Mercedes-Benz national organization of the country of assembly.

Visiting Vehicles

  • Canadian vehicles have the 48 month/80,000 kilometers (50,000 miles) Canadian New Vehicle Warranty, which does not include Roadside Assistance. Select Warranty Extensions may be honored if applicable to the respective VIN as noted on VMI and also if an EVA Coverage Check returns 100% coverage for the Warranty Extension in question. Select emission warranty repairs will be honored as well as determined by the Canadian emissions warranty coverage terms for the respective VIN in question.
  • Canadian Recall campaigns may be supported. Service Campaigns should not be performed.
    • If the customer’s length of visit in the US is greater than 6 mos. or the vehicle is registered within the USA – dealer should open a Star Support case for feedback/approval
  • Certain market specific contracts or warranties cannot be covered in the US (such as ELW/CPO/PPM)
  • Any further market warranties/goodwill arrangements must be claimed by the customer through their home dealer.
Warranty extensions are an additional time and mileage coverage granted to specific components on a customer’s vehicle. If the vehicle has an applicable extension, it will appear on VMI.

Owners who have previously paid to have a repair done for a warrantable condition under a warranty extension may be eligible for a reimbursement. The dealer must review all documentation to make sure the vehicle is eligible. Claim submission procedure is as follows:

  • Create a claim using new RO number and entering date and miles from when original repair was performed
  • Attach supporting documents to the claim
  • Original or clear copy of all receipts, invoices and/or repair orders must be provided by the customer. The documents provided must contain all relevant information required for the warranty extension (codes, VIN, date, miles. part number(s), etc.).
    • Only repairs completed with Genuine MB parts will be considered eligible
  • Customer reimbursement should be on its own Repair Order and submitted as a sublet on the claim. Reimbursement may be limited to the amount the repair would have cost if completed by an authorized Mercedes-Benz dealer.
MBUSA will repair under warranty any manufacturing defect for an accessory that was purchased from and installed by an authorized MB Dealer. Damages and outside influence are not covered.

Technical Accessories are equipment/parts that are installed in or mounted on the vehicle after the vehicle has left the factory. For claim submission of technical accessories, refer to Damage Code > Group 58.

Collection Accessories are those items (clothing, watches, umbrellas, etc.) that are sold independently of the vehicle usage. To check warranty coverage for a Genuine Mercedes-Benz Accessory, please refer to ODUS

The MBCPO limited warranty applies to covered repairs to the vehicle occurring within the United States or Puerto Rico. During the specified warranty period, all necessary repairs or replacements of parts listed will be made by any authorized MB dealer at no charge to correct defects in material or workmanship in covered parts and/or systems of a MB CPO vehicle.

• For vehicles with remaining NVLW, the NVLW remains in effect for its original term and the MBCPO Limited Warranty begins after NVLW ends.
  • For vehicles without remaining NVLW, the MBCPO warranty coverage is for 12 months from the MBCPO delivery date.
  • For vehicles with an Optional Extended Limited Warranty, coverage is 1 year/Unlimited Mileage or 2 years/Unlimited Mileage beyond the time duration of the MBCPO limited warranty.
  • If a part is not listed, it is not covered.
To obtain details on the Mercedes-Benz CPO program and/or policy, please contact the Dealer Support Center.
This section includes a chart as an example that outlines coverage by years and miles. Refer to the respective vehicle’s Service and Warranty Booklet found in XENTRY Workshop.
Chart does not show any limitations to warranty coverage, for exclusions refer to Policy 2.1.

Excluded from the warranty are faults, damage and wear that are not the responsibility of the manufacturer. The same applies to indirect costs that are incurred due to damage covered by warranty, including vehicle transport costs, freight costs and costs for various special solutions.

The following is not an all inclusive list of damage which is excluded from warranty. This information is also located in the Service and Warranty Booklets.

  • Damage due to lack of maintenance
  • Damage due to accidents, misuse or negligence
  • Normal maintenance is the owner’s responsibility
  • Damage due to alterations
  • Damage caused by aftermarket parts or incorrect fuel
  • Mileage tampering
  • Damage from the environment
  • Damage resulting from racing or other competitive events

Coverage should always be verified through ESKULAB as time/mileage limitations are based on Damage Type. If an item comes back covered, but was not caused by a manufacturing defect, a claim must not be filed.
Below is an alphabetical list of coverage for certain vehicle components. Always verify coverage through ESKULAB as time/mileage limitations are based on Damage Type.

articles.tableData::
ITEM EXPLANATION
Adjustments Adjustments (i.e. Door, Hood or Trunk Striker, Glass, Headlight, Throttle Linkage or Transmission Linkage) are covered for the first adjustment only during the NVLW except where the adjustments should be part of normal pre-delivery service or part of a regular maintenance service. Subsequent adjustments are dealer responsibility.
Battery – Vehicle / Original Equipment Warranty coverage does not apply to breakage of the container, cover posts, or to a battery that has been opened, dropped, frozen, or otherwise damaged due to obvious misuse; or when markings on the case or posts have been destroyed or altered; or a discharged battery due to lack of maintenance on vehicles in dealer stock. Batteries replaced within 30 days or less than 50 miles after Retail Date are the responsibility of the selling dealer.
For vehicle models listed in SI54.10-P-0074A, a XENTRY Diagnosis battery test has to be performed. The completed test log 12V starter battery from XENTRY Diagnosis containing the test results will be required. For warranty and goodwill repairs, this test log with test result must be uploaded into pXD. For vehicle models NOT listed in SI54.10-P-0074A, a Midtronics battery test has to be performed and a permanent legible copy of the test results printout marked with the date and Vehicle Identification Number retained in the vehicle service history file for all vehicle battery replacements as well as vehicle scheduled maintenance checks. Since the test printout becomes illegible overtime, we recommend that the document be scanned or a photo copy be retained with the vehicle service history file. Batteries that are found to be in need of replacement during a CPO inspection may be claimed under warranty (if applicable) providing that a Midtronics test or for vehicle models listed in SI54.10-P-0074A, a XENTRY Diagnosis battery test, has to be performed within 48 hours of receiving the vehicle at the dealership . The Midtronics test or XENTRY test needs to show that the battery is in need of replacement and all Repair Order requirements still need to be adhered to (e.g. time punching, mileage, etc.).
Battery – High Voltage Hybrid and High Voltage battery coverage varies based on Model Year and /or State, refer to the respective vehicle's Service and Warranty Information booklet.
High-voltage batteries replaced while the vehicle is in dealer inventory require proper maintenance / documentation and it must be retained in the Vehicle History file for determination of warranty coverage.
Battery – Remote Control Key (Original Equipment / Replacement) Remote Control Key Batteries (original equipment) or from the battery purchase date (replacement) carry a lesser coverage than the NVLW, refer to ESKULAB coverage based on Repair Order open date vehicle time / mileage.
Brake Discs Brake Discs for defects in material or factory workmanship for 24 months or 31,000 miles, except replacement due to normal maintenance or wear, carry a lesser coverage than the NVLW, refer to ESKULAB coverage based on Repair Order open date vehicle time / mileage.
Brake Pads Brake Pads for defects in material or factory workmanship, except replacement due to normal maintenance or wear, carry a lesser coverage than the NVLW, refer to ESKULAB coverage based on Repair Order open date vehicle time / mileage.
Brake System Bleeding Brake System Bleeding is related to normal maintenance is not covered except when necessary as a component of a warrantable repair.
Chrome Chrome is covered during the NVLW for defects in material or workmanship (peeling or discoloration). Chrome is not covered if damaged due to lack of care or as a result of exposure to the elements or chemical influence (road salts, industrial fallout, use of improper cleaners, polishes, waxes, etc.).
Clutch Discs and Pressure Plates Replacement of clutch discs and pressure plates (manual transmission) is considered an owner maintenance item and is not covered (customer responsibility).
Convertible Tops Defects in material or factory workmanship, such as split seams, cracks, etc. are covered during the NVLW Convertible tops and flexible windowpanes are not covered when damaged, creased, or wrinkled as a result of being improperly serviced, cleaned, or folded down into the space behind the rear seat backrest. Tops are not covered when damaged by exposure to the elements, chemical influence, road salts, industrial fallout, or the use of improper cleaners. Fading, soiling, and normal wear and tear are not covered.
Corrosion Corrosion is covered during the NVLW for repair or replacement of sheet metal panels, which are corroded due to rust. Holes due to cosmetic or surface corrosion resulting from such things as stone chips, industrial fallout, sand, salt, hail or scratches in the paint are not covered.
Electrical Short Basic coverage for correction of an electrical short or open circuit due to defect in material or factory workmanship is covered during the NVLW. THERE IS NO COVERAGE FOR DAMAGE AS A RESULT OF IMPROPERLY INSTALLED EXTRA EQUIPMENT (e.g. RADAR DETECTOR, TELEPHONE, etc.)
Engine Tune-up Engine Tune-Up is considered an owner maintenance item and is not covered (customer responsibility)., except when necessary as a component for a warrantable repair.
Excessive Oil Consumption Normal oil consumption is one quart in 600 miles. No attempts to repair should be made until the engine has accrued 5,000 miles to allow for break-in. The WIS Oil Consumption Form must accompany the warranty return engine and a copy must be placed in the vehicle history file. Refer to Section Required Documentation for Engines
Filters (i.e. Air, Oil, Fuel, Transmission, etc) Filters are covered by Emission Performance & California Emission Warranties until part has been replaced at the first replacement interval as part of regular maintenance. Otherwise, filters are maintenance items and considered owner responsibility.
Fluids Oil, lubricants and fluids (examples of fluids provided below) are not covered except when necessary as a component of a warrantable repair
Examples of Fluids include but are not limited to: Transmission and Hydraulic Fluids, Windshield Washer Fluid, Anti-Freeze, Brake Fluid, Power Steering Fluid, Transfer Case Fluid, Differential Fluid, AdBlue
Glass Coverage Replacement due to Defects: Glass is warranted against defects such as bubbles, distortion, discoloration, and de-lamination during the NVLW. Unless positive physical proof of a manufacturing responsibility can be established, scratches are not claimable.
Due to Stress Cracks: Glass is warranted against stress cracks for 12 months or 12,000 miles, whichever occurs first.
Paint and Sheet Metal Paint and sheet metal is warranted for defects in material or factory workmanship that actually detract from the overall appearance of the vehicle. Cleaning, polishing, removal of minor blemishes, and hairline scratches, and brush touch-up work are all considered part of the dealer’s Delivery Certification. Paint damaged by gravel, sand, road salts, dust-laying chemicals, tar, oil, industrial fallout or foreign substances, excessive rubbing or the use of improper cleaners, polishes, or waxes, and atmospheric conditions beyond MBUSA’s control are not covered.
Areas refinished by qualified personnel using approved products and procedures carry a limited warranty provided by the paint supplier. Contact the paint supplier directly for details. Do not submit warranty claims to MBUSA for repairs to refinished areas.
Refrigerant Replacement of refrigerant is claimable only when necessary because of a warranty eligible repair. Refrigerant does not break down over time and is considered owner responsibility.
Seatbelts Seatbelts are covered during the NVLW with the exception of coverage in the state of Kansas which is 10 yrs./Unlimited Mileage.
Spark Plugs Spark plugs are subject to consumption during their normal service life and their replacement is regarded as part of owner maintenance at the mileage/time specified for the vehicle model in the Maintenance/Service booklet. The use of other than the standard heat range plug is at times required to meet unusual operating conditions to which some vehicles are subjected. The installation of such plugs is not subject to coverage under warranty. Plugs that become fouled should not be replaced under warranty since the plug itself is not defective. These plugs can usually be cleaned and reinstalled with satisfactory results.
Spark Plugs Wire Sets Bosch Limited Lifetime Warranty period begins on the day the product is delivered to the original consumer/purchaser and is not transferable to subsequent owners of the product.
BNA has reached an agreement with MBUSA to handle the warranty as follows:
  • If a vehicle is beyond warranty, and the Bosch ignition kit is installed or was previously installed during the NVLW, MBUSA will accept a claim for any subsequent defects from the authorized Mercedes-Benz installing dealer for the original customer/purchaser for PARTS ONLY.
  • If the vehicle is beyond warranty, and one or more ignition wires are replaced with DAG wires, the MBUSA Limited Service Parts and Accessories Warranty would apply for any subsequent defects.
Tires Original equipment tires will be covered for ride disturbance for 12 months/6,000 miles or 12 months/12,000 miles under the NVLW for manufacturing defects using damage code 21506. Refer to the respective Tire Manufacturer's Pamphlet for further information on the Tire Manufacturer's Warranty.
The warranty covers defects in material or workmanship in original equipment tires arising during the warranty period until there is 2/32 inch (1.6 mm) of tread depth remaining over the entire tread surface. No warranty coverage is applicable to tires with less tread depth than 2/32-inch (1.6 mm) or for any damage resulting in improper tire inflation or tire rotation maintenance.
Examples of damage not covered (not an all inclusive list)
  • Impact or road hazard damages such as punctures, cuts, snags, bruises
  • Incorrect wheel alignment
  • Excessive axle load
  • Racing or competitive driving
  • Improper repair i.e mounting or puncture repair
The replacement tires provided under warranty must be of the type, size and brand approved by MBUSA for the particular vehicle model. MBUSA will not reimburse dealers for replacement tires that are not specifically approved by MBUSA either directly or through Dealer Tire for the specific Mercedes-Benz vehicle involved. In the event that MBUSA or its authorized Tire Limited Warranty claim administrator, Dealer Tire, deems the original model tires are not available, MBUSA or Dealer Tire, as applicable, will authorize what replacement tires can be used as a warranty replacement.
Upholstery (Soft Trim) Defects in material or factory workmanship, such as split seams, cracks, etc. are covered during the NVLW. Soft trim is not covered when damaged by exposure to the elements, chemical influence, road salts, industrial fallout, or the use of improper cleaners. Fading, soiling, and normal wear and tear are not covered.
Wheel Alignment MBUSA will pay for the first adjustment only during the first 12 months or 12,000 miles when performed at a certified Mercedes-Benz dealer. Subsequent adjustments are the dealer’s responsibility. Before and after wheel alignment readings generated by the MB approved wheel alignment equipment must be kept in the vehicle service history file. For warranty claiming purposes, if an alignment is needed (as a separate operation) due to the replacement of a covered component, the labor and bolt kit (if required) must be claimed on the same line as the original failed part and not on a separate line.
As for the retention of alignment specification sheets, which are required to be retained with the respective repair order in the vehicle history files, there is only one acceptable printout. The printout includes official Mercedes-Benz/Daimler header and footer information that must be found on all printouts. An example of the approved printout showing the header and footer information is attached (click on the link below to view). The body of the printout, containing the before and after readings will vary by manufacturer, however, the header and footer will remain consistent.
All ride height data must be transferred to the alignment console via the required Romess docking station. Any alignments/repairs performed with manually entered ride heights or missing any required alignment data (i.e. customer information, VIN number, tire information, tire pressure, tread depth, date, repair order number and all before and after alignment readings) may be subject to debit. Handwritten information is not acceptable. Please refer to the attached link for an example.
Adjustments for road crown issues are not covered.
Wiper Blades / Inserts Wiper Blades or Wiper Blade Inserts for defects in material or factory workmanship carry a lesser coverage than the NVLW, refer to ESKULAB coverage based on Repair Order open date vehicle time/mileage.
Note: Damaged or worn wiper blades/wiper blade inserts are NOT covered.

The New Vehicle Limited Warranty is the original manufacturer's warranty (4 years/50,000 miles; whichever occurs first) that comes with the purchase of a new Mercedes-Benz vehicle. Emission coverage varies by state. ESKULAB Coverage should always be used to determine eligibility of warranty coverage using the RO open date.

rh:doc.parentIdentifier9: PC 1. Receipt, Storage and Delivery of Vehicles

articles.content: Dealers are responsible for New Vehicle Preparation. It is a certification by the dealer that the new vehicle has been prepared for retail delivery in accordance with MBUSA required procedures.

• Minor labor-only repairs, which are part of new vehicle preparation or considered the dealer's obligation, are not covered under warranty and a warranty claim will not be accepted by MBUSA.
  • The Pre-Delivery Inspection includes the checking and erasing of diagnostic trouble codes (DTC's) on those vehicle systems that can be diagnosed with XENTRY.
  • Separate claims for checking or erasing DTC’s that are considered as part of the Pre-Delivery Inspection will not be accepted by the Manufacturer.
  • DTC’s which are not part of the Pre-Delivery Inspection, and require additional attention (testing and repairs), are to be handled and submitted as separate repairs.
  • Vehicles delivered with missing or incorrect equipment will require a claim submitted in EVA damage coded to the part.
The Pre-Delivery Inspection must be completed electronically and can be printed, searched and viewed by using the electronic PDI system in XENTRY.

Authorized Mercedes-Benz dealers are to adhere to the following New Vehicle Preparation procedures:

  • The dealer is responsible for every part of the Pre-Delivery Inspection Form including that of new vehicle inspection, delivery, and providing instructions/explanation on vehicle operation to the new vehicle owner. MBUSA will continue to carry out inspection of new vehicles at the VPC and plant prior to shipment to the Mercedes-Benz dealership.
  • Failure or damage of parts due to an improper Pre-Delivery Inspection process is not covered under warranty.
  • New vehicle preparation must be correct prior to delivery to the first retail Owner.
  • The new vehicle preparation work, including the Service Re-check portion, must be performed prior to delivery of the new vehicle to the retail Owner within a sufficient timeframe that allows for any necessary required repairs discovered during the new vehicle preparation work to be completed prior to delivery.
  • The dealer must complete the "New Vehicle System Checkout/Inspection” section of the Owner's Service and Warranty Information booklet.
  • Each dealer must establish a definite new vehicle preparation procedure in order to maintain quality control.
  • The new vehicle preparation work must be assigned to fully qualified service personnel.
  • The dealer must complete the Pre-Delivery Inspection form electronically, using either the PDA or desktop version on XENTRY. The Pre-Delivery Inspection form is a certification by the dealer that the new vehicle has been prepared for retail delivery in accordance with MBUSA required procedures. Upon completion of the Pre-Delivery Inspection form, retain the Pre-Delivery Inspection form in the vehicle history file for 7 years or however long the dealer maintains its file with respect to the subject vehicle, whichever is longer.
  • Warrantable repairs that are not included as part of the new vehicle preparation work as indicated on the Pre-Delivery Inspection Form, must be submitted to MBUSA as a separate warranty claim.
  • Submission of warranty claims for the Pre-Delivery Inspection is not necessary. Payment for the New Pre-Delivery Inspection is based upon the wholesale date (this includes wholesale date of consigned vehicles) in NetStar and is paid to the dealer code that actually performs the PDI via the ePDI tool/application.
  • Payment information is shown daily in all applicable sections of the R22 credit note list. The repair order number listed on the R22 credit note list is generated by MBUSA for the automatic payment of the PDI.
  • Pre-Delivery Inspection is paid ONLY once per VIN. Note: If vehicle is traded from originally consigned dealer to another MB dealer, the PDI will not be paid a second time to the newly acquiring dealer. The trading dealer and acquiring dealer will need to liaise between themselves in order to rectify reimbursement/payment of the PDI from the original dealer to the acquiring dealer. The payment will be activated once the PDI technician completes the PDI, through either the PDA or desktop version in XENTRY. If the dealer does not complete the PDI electronically, the payment will not be made to the dealer.
  • All Delivery Certifications must be time-punched separately.
  • Pre-Delivery Inspection payment is based on the dealer's current approved warranty labor rate multiplied by the applicable model's time allowance as published in XENTRY Operation Time.
  • PDI payments are not paid on European Delivery Vehicles or Armed Forces (Oversea) vehicle purchases. Vehicles with option code 820 Tourist Vehicles are excluded from PDI payments.
Note: To assure correct preparation of a new vehicle prior to delivery, quality checks of vehicles, which have undergone the Pre-Delivery Inspection, will be made by MBUSA regional personnel. These regional spot checks serve as a tool in assisting and evaluating a dealer's Pre-Delivery Inspection performance. Pre-Delivery Inspection “on” and “off” (i.e. Start and End) time must be clocked separately and labeled as “DC” on the repair order issued for the performance of the new vehicle preparation.

rh:doc.headline: PC 1.1 Storage
rh:doc.parentIdentifier9: PC 1. Receipt, Storage and Delivery of Vehicles

articles.content: Stored vehicles are to be protected and maintained up to factory standards.

Criteria that must be adhered to:

  • Proper protection and maintenance prior to retail is solely dealer's responsibility.
  • Any damages or needed repairs must be completed prior to dealer storage.
  • Vehicle must be stored/parked on a paved or permanently hard surface.
  • To avoid airborne fallout, vehicles should not be stored under lights, power lines/poles or trees.
  • If exposed to sunlight, vehicle position should be rotated every 30 days to avoid sun damage.
  • Vehicle must be stored in well drained dry location to prevent rust or water/flood damage.
  • Soft trim should be cleaned to avoid/prevent premature deterioration.
  • The vehicle’s interior must be kept dry and actions must be taken to prevent moisture from condensing inside the vehicle.
  • To avoid tire flat spots and brake pulsation and vibration, the vehicle must be moved to a new parking spot or moved forward or backward at least one half tire rotation every 30 days.
  • Tire pressure must also be checked and maintained at the maximum MBUSA recommended tire pressure, at least once every 30 days.
For vehicles being placed in storage reference WIS ap00.70-p-1000zz and si54.10-p-0024a for battery information.
